In Chambers's Household Sh. is the following note: 'We have adopted "oft subdue" [for "of a doubt"], suggested by Mr Swynfen Jervis, and thus supported:—Son. iii, 6; and All's Well, V, iii, 217.' Bailey (ii, 2): For 'eale' read evil; for 'of a doubt' read oft weigh down. 'Weigh, in some of the old copies of Hamlet, is spelt way.' Compare Rich. III: V, iii, 153; Timon V, i, 154.
Arrowsmith thus quotes the passage: 'The dram of base Doth all the noble substance often draw To,' &c.

Strachey: Hamlet's generalizations are really drawn from the excessive brooding over his own character and circumstances, and only afterwards applied to the men and things about him. It is plainly he himself who is the original of this his description of the man in whom either nature or circumstances have unduly developed some one tendency of the character, to the injury of the proper and rational balance and harmony of the whole; and who, in consequence of this one defect, for which he is not responsible, and should rather be pitied than blamed, is looked on with disparagement by the world, however excellent all his other qualities may be.

In Davies's Dram. Misc. (iii, 29) an account is given from Cibber of Betterton's acting in this scene; Betterton was taught by Sir William Davenant, who had seen Taylor, one of the original performers of Hamlet [see V, ii, 274]: 'He opened the scene with a pause of mute amazement; then, rising slowly to a solemn, trembling voice, he made the Ghost equally terrible to the spectator and himself; and, in the descriptive part of the natural emotions which the ghastly vision gave him, the boldness of his expostulation was still governed by decency; manly, but not braving; his voice never rising to that seeming outrage or wild defiance of what he naturally revered.' Booth said: 'When I acted the Ghost with Betterton, instead of my awing him, he terrified me. But divinity hung round that man.' On the other hand, Macklin, after the first line, spoke the rest of the address calmly but respectfully, and with a firm tone of voice, as from one who had subdued his timidity and apprehension. Booth, says Davies, has never been surpassed in his acting of the Ghost; his slow, solemn, and undertone of voice, his noiseless tread, as if he had been composed of air, created a powerful impression. Hunter (ii, 222): 'The idea of surprise predominates over the idea of apprehension. He did not mean that he needed protection in the presence of so gracious a figure, and the exclamation must be understood to escape him almost involuntarily. A pretty long pause should ensue after it is spoken, to allow him to recollect himself.' A stage direction [Pause] is added after this line by Collier (ed. ii), with the note: This minute stage direction, showing the particular manner of the old actor of the character of Hamlet, ought to be preserved, and is from the (MS). It seems natural that the performer should 'pause' to recover breath after this exclamation, and before he tremblingly proceeds to question the Ghost. We believe that the modern practice on our stage has been uniform in this respect,—possibly from the oldest tradition. [See Lichtenberg's account of Garrick, in the Appendix. Ed.]
Clarendon: A healed or saved spirit.

Nichols (i, 27) advocates 'events' of Ff, in the sense of 'coming forth.' 'The Ghost had already appeared twice,—this was the third time of his coming forth?' Corson: The reading of the Ff is better than that of the Qq. Events is equivalent to issues. The meaning is, not that Hamlet attributes any intents to the Ghost, but that the Ghost's appearance is to him prognostic of certain issues or events; 'thy' is the personal, and not the possessive, adjective pronoun; in other words, it is used objectively.
Theobald: That is, to be conversed with, inviting question, as in Macb. I, iii, 43. Caldecott: 'So doubtful, that I will at least make inquiry to obtain a solution.'

Pye (p. 312): The change of punctuation proposed in the following anonymous observation, published in the St. James's Chronicle, 15 Oct. 1761, is so convincing that I shall without hesitation adopt it: '[To put a colon after "Dane"] seems to be a strange climax (if not an anti-climax). But a slight alteration in the pointing will remove all objections, preserve the beauty of the climax, and perhaps give an additional force to the whole passage. Thus, "I'll call thee Hamlet, King, Father,—Royal Dane, O answer me." The climax naturally and beautifully ends with the endearing appellation of "Father." He then addresses the Ghost by the general appellation, "Royal Dane, O answer me."' This seems the criticism of no mean critic, [Mr Edwin Booth has informed me that his father always spoke the line thus, and that he himself has always so spoken it. I believe Mr Irving has also adopted it. To me it is unquestionably the true reading, and I have not hesitated to punctuate the text accordingly. Ed.]

Warburton: Bones over which the rites of sepulture have been performed, or which were buried according to the canon. Blakeway: The accent is on the second syllable. [See Walker, Vers. 197; Abbott, § 491.] 51–54: Johnson has a long note on these lines, called forth by Warburton's superfluous change of 'hearsed in earth' and sums up the whole sentence in: 'Why dost thou appear, whom we know to be dead?' Heath (p. 531): By the expression hearsed in death is meant, shut up and secured with all those precautions which are usually practised in preparing dead bodies for sepulture, such as the winding-sheet, shroud, coffin, &c. So that death is here used, by a metonymy of the antecedent for the consequent, for the rites of death, such as are generally esteemed due, and practised with regard to dead bodies.

Clarendon: Q1 here reads 'ceremonies.' As this copy is probably derived from short-hand notes taken at the play, it would seem to show that 'cerements' was pronounced as a trisyllable. [Does it not rather show that 'ceremonies' was pronounced as a trisyllable: 'cer'monies'? and is it not an additional proof of what Staunton and Walker affirm in reference to the monosyllabic pronunciation of cere in ceremony, ceremonious, ceremonials? See Macb. III, iv, 36. Ed.] See Cotgrave: 'Cerat: A Plaister made of Waxe, Gummes, &c, and certaine oyles wee also, call it, a Cerot or Searecloth.'

Dyce: In my Few Notes, &c., p. 137, I remarked: 'Perhaps the reading of the Qq is preferable, because in-urn'd implies that the body had been reduced to ashes,'—a remark which I now wish to recall. Compare Cor. V, vi, 145, 146. Clarendon: 'Urn' is used for 'grave' in Hen. V: I, ii, 228.

Caldecott (i, 126): Deprive you of the command of your reason, of that sovereignty which you now exercise over it. So that he throws his image forcibly before his reader, Shakespeare leaves it to him to arrange his pronouns and articles, and grammatically thread his meaning. Compare 'nobility of love,' I, ii, 110. For instances where pronominal and other adjectives are placed before a whole compound noun instead of, as they strictly should be, before the second of the two nouns, see Abbott, § 423. So 'your cause of distemper,' III. ii, 321; 'His means of death,' i.e. 'the means of his death.'—IV, v, 207. 'My better part of man.' — Macb. V, viii, 18.

Theobald, Caldecott, and Clarendon say that in strict grammar us should be here used; but Walker [Crit. i, 58] evidently, as Lettsom notes, connects 'we fools' with 'That,' and so does Moberly in his excellent paraphrase: 'What may it mean that we with our blind nature (are made) so horribly to shake our composure of spirit with thoughts beyond the reach of our souls?' adding; 'This random connexion of the clause suits well with the headlong impetuosity of the speech.' On the same grammatical grounds Tschischwitz reads, 'So horridly do shake.' Abbott, § 216, thus explains 'and we': After a conjunction and before an infinitive we often find I, thou, &c., where in Latin we should have 'me,' 'te,' &c. The conjunction seems to be regarded as introducing a new sentence, instead of connecting one clause with another. Hence the pronoun is put in the nominative, and a verb is, perhaps, to be supplied from the context. So, too, we have 'we' for us in III, ii, 231, since it stands quasi-independently at some distance from the governing word, 'touches.'

Warburton: Intimating that we are only kept (as formerly fools in a great family) to make sport for nature, who lies hid only to mock and laugh at us for our vain searches into her mysteries. Mason (p. 378): A paraphrase of the common expression, natural fools. Clarendon: Playthings of nature, completely under her influence. See Meas. for Meas. III, i, 11.
Walker: Wherefore often varies in accent, and is often used for why.

Cambridge Editors: Steevens says, 'F1 reads remote.' We have not been able to find this reading in any copy of that edition which we have consulted. Sir Frederic Madden has kindly collated for us the four copies in the British Museum, all of which have 'removed.' This is also the reading of Capell's copy, of Malone's, and of two others to which we have had access, and it is the reading in Mr Booth's reprint. [It is also the reading in my copy of F1. Ed.]
Abbott: For instances of 'should' denoting a statement not made by the speaker, like sollen in German.
Dyce: 'Set...at a pin's fee'—i.e. not care for at all.
Warburton: Hamlet risks damnation by going; bold, but foolhardy.
Hunter: An allusion to what many persons feel when on lofty heights, a desire of throwing themselves headlong.

Delius: The substance of these lines Shakespeare afterwards introduced, much enlarged and elaborated, into King Lear, just as he introduced into Jul. Cæsar a passage that had been erased from the first scene of Hamlet. This probably accounts for the omission of these lines in the Ff.
Johnson: Here 'deprive' means simply to take away.
Steevens: Among our old writers, 'let' signifies to prevent or hinder. It is still current in the law. Clarendon: Compare Romans, i, 13, and 2 Thessalonians, ii, 7.

1.play: Ghost: Whither wilt thou lead me? speak; I'll go no further.
notes: Douce: These words are turned into ridicule in The Woman Hater, Beau, and Fl. vol. i, p. 37, ed. Dyce.
Delius: Hamlet uses the word in the sense of ready addressed [past part, of Old Norse buinn, — see Wedgwood], the Ghost uses it as the past participle of the verb to bind.
Seymour: The use of "I will" is Hamlet’s acceptance of the Ghost’s invitation.

4.play: Ghost: My hour is almost come,

5.play: Ghost: When I to sulphurous and tormenting flames
notes: Clarendon: "Sulphurous and tormenting flames" refers to the fires of purgatory, following the Catholic doctrine.

8.play: Ghost: Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing

9.play: Ghost: To what I shall unfold.

10.play: Hamlet: Speak; I am bound to hear.

11.play: Ghost: So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear.
notes: Theobald: The expression "to fast in fires" is metaphorical; fasting purifies the soul just as fire purifies in purgatory.

13.play: Ghost: I am thy father's spirit;

14.play: Ghost: Doom'd for a certain term to walk the night,
notes: Farmer: Thus Gawain Douglas, in his translation of AEn. vi, 740, says that "it is a nedeful thing to suffer panis and torment...some in the wyndis, sum under the watter, and in the fire uthir sum. Till the mony vices Contrakkit in the corpis be done away And purgit."

15.play: Ghost: And for the day confined to fast in fires,

16.play: Ghost: Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature

17.play: Ghost: Are burnt and purged away. But that I am forbid

18.play: Ghost: To tell the secrets of my prison-house,

19.play: Ghost: I could a tale unfold whose lightest word
notes: Abbott: For the omission and insertion of "to" in the same sentence, see Abbott, § 350, and I, v, 178.

20.play: Ghost: Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,

21.play: Ghost: Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres,

22.play: Ghost: Thy knotted and combined locks to part
notes: Walker: Walker (Crit. i, 62) proposes "infernal," and cites it among instances of an inaccurate use of words in Shakespeare—"imperfect, I say, for he was not an ignorant man, even on this point, and others common to him with his contemporaries."

23.play: Ghost: And each particular hair to stand an end,

24.play: Ghost: Like quills upon the fretful porpentine:

25.play: Ghost: But this eternal blazon must not be

26.play: Ghost: To ears of flesh and blood. List, list, O, list!
notes: Caldecott: "Such promulgation of the mysteries of eternity must not be made to beings of a day."

27.play: Ghost: If thou didst ever thy dear father love—

29.play: Ghost: Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder.
notes: Seymour: Seymour (ii, 159) considers this as an unnecessary interpolation of some actors; so also the Ghost's repetition of "Murder" in line 31.

31.play: Ghost: Murder most foul, as in the best it is;

32.play: Ghost: But this most foul, strange, and unnatural.
notes: Warburton: This word is consecrated by the mystics to signify that flight of mind which aspires to the enjoyment of the supreme Good. So that the two most rapid things in nature are here employed: the ardency of divine and human passion in an enthusiast and a lover.

33.play: Hamlet: Haste me to know't, that I, with wings as swift
notes: Theobald: Theobald (Sh. Rest. p. 50) conjectured "swoop" instead of "sweep," but did not repeat this conjecture in his edition.
Clarendon: For instances of "should" where we now use "would," see Abbott, § 332, or Macbeth III, vi, 19.

34.play: Hamlet: As meditation or the thoughts of love,

35.play: Hamlet: May sweep to my revenge.

37.play: Ghost: And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed

38.play: Ghost: That roots itself in ease on Lethe wharf,
notes: Capell: Capell (i, 127) remarks the use of "roots" rather than "rots" for the sense of inaction rather than action.

39.play: Ghost: Wouldst thou not stir in this. Now, Hamlet, hear:

40.play: Ghost: 'Tis given out, that, sleeping in my orchard,

41.play: Ghost: A serpent stung me; so the whole ear of Denmark
notes: Clarendon: "Process" here means an official narrative; see the Epistle to the English Drama and Stage (Roxburghhe Library), p. 17.

42.play: Ghost: Is by a forged process of my death

43.play: Ghost: Rankly abused; but know, thou noble youth,

44.play: Ghost: The serpent that did sting thy father's life

46.play: Hamlet: O my prophetic soul! My uncle?

47.play: Ghost: Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast,
notes: Clarendon: "Adulterate" is used in the sense of "emulous." See Lover's Complaint 175.

48.play: Ghost: With witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts—

49.play: Ghost: O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power

50.play: Ghost: So to seduce!—won to his shameful lust

51.play: Ghost: The will of my most seeming-virtuous queen.

52.play: Ghost: O Hamlet, what a falling-off was there!
notes: Clarendon: An inaccurate construction, like one found in Bacon, Advancement of Learning: "for his government civil, though he did not attain to that of Trajan's," &c.

53.play: Ghost: From me, whose love was of that dignity
notes: Abbott: For instances of the noun absolute ("virtue" has here no verb), see Abbott, § 417.

54.play: Ghost: That it went hand in hand even with the vow

55.play: Ghost: I made to her in marriage; and to decline

56.play: Ghost: Upon a wretch, whose natural gifts were poor
notes: Tschischwitz: The reading of Qq makes excellent sense, even without changing "in" to "from." "Even in a celestial bed lust will separate, detach itself, etc."

58.play: Ghost: But virtue, as it never will be moved,

59.play: Ghost: Though lewdness court it in a shape of heaven,

60.play: Ghost: So lust, though to a radiant angel link'd,
notes: Dyce: "These fires were those of Purgatory, in which the Ghost was confined for the day only and so were not lasting."

61.play: Ghost: Will sate itself in a celestial bed

63.play: Ghost: But, soft! methinks I scent the morning air;

64.play: Ghost: Brief let me be. Sleeping within my orchard,

65.play: Ghost: My custom always in the afternoon,

66.play: Ghost: Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole,
notes: Hudson: Shakespeare here implies as much as was then known touching the circulation of the blood.

67.play: Ghost: With juice of cursed hebenon in a vial,

68.play: Ghost: And in the porches of my ears did pour
notes: Clarendon: The only instance in Shakespeare of "posset" as a verb.

69.play: Ghost: The leperous distilment; whose effect
notes: Clarendon: Cotgrave gives: "Aigre: Eagre, sharpe, tart, biting, sower."

70.play: Ghost: Holds such an enmity with blood of man

71.play: Ghost: That, swift as quicksilver, it courses through

72.play: Ghost: The natural gates and alleys of the body;

73.play: Ghost: And with a sudden vigour it doth posset

74.play: Ghost: And curd, like eager droppings into milk,

75.play: Ghost: The thin and wholesome blood; so did it mine;
notes: Warburton: "Dispatch'd" is used in the sense of 'bereft.' Dyce (Few Notes, p. 139) prefers the sense of sudden loss.

76.play: Ghost: And a most instant tetter bark'd about,

77.play: Ghost: Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust,
notes: Theobald: From the old Saxon word for the sacrament: husel. Spenser calls the sacramental fire the housling fire.
Johnson: "Disappointed" is the same as "unappointed," and may be properly explained unprepared; a man well furnished with things necessary for any enterprise is said to be well appointed.

Caldecott: In the advertisement to his notes, Stephen Weston quotes Sophocles, Antigone, 1071: h[ioipov, ciK-epiCTov, avdoiov vekvv, and adds: h[ioipov, disappointed or unprovided, unportioned, unprepared with sacrifices for the infernal gods; avooiov, unhouseled, without the sacrament or holy rites; mcrepicrovf, unaneled, without the holy oil or the honors of burial.

79.play: Ghost: Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother's hand

80.play: Ghost: Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch'd;
notes: Johnson: It was ingeniously hinted to me by a very learned lady that this line seems to belong to Hamlet, in whose mouth it is a proper and natural exclamation.

81.play: Ghost: Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
notes: Seymour: Hamlet does not lament that the disjointed time is to be set right by him, but that he, whose duty it becomes by necessity to set the time right, should have been born.

83.play: Ghost: No reckoning made, but sent to my account

84.play: Ghost: With all my imperfections on my head.

85.play: Ghost: Oh, horrible! oh, horrible! most horrible!

86.play: Ghost: If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not;
notes: Dyce (Gloss.): "Luxury" means lasciviousness, its only sense in Shakespeare.

87.play: Ghost: Let not the royal bed of Denmark be

88.play: Ghost: A couch for luxury and damned incest.

89.play: Ghost: But, howsoever thou pursuest this act,
notes: Elze: "Matin" is rare in this sense; Drake prints "matins" in his citation.

90.play: Ghost: Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive
notes: Warburton: "Uneffectual fire" as fire that is seen but without heat. Steevens: Rather, fire that is no longer seen when morning approaches.

91.play: Ghost: Against thy mother aught; leave her to heaven,
notes: Douce: It was the popular belief that ghosts could not endure the light, and consequently disappeared at the dawn of day.

92.play: Ghost: And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge,

93.play: Ghost: To prick and sting her. Fare thee well at once!

94.play: Ghost: The glow-worm shows the matin to be near,

95.play: Ghost: And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire;

96.play: Ghost: Adieu, adieu, adieu! remember me. [Exit.]
notes: Stage Direction] Owing to the length of time that elapses before the companions of Ham. rejoin him, Delius thinks it unlikely that the dialogue with the Ghost took place on the same Platform where Ham. broke loose from his friends. TscmscHWlTZ changes the scene to 'A Wilderness,' because • Ham. must have followed the Ghost a long distance, since he refuses to go farther. His question also, " Whither wilt thou lead me?" shows that, despite his courage, horror is beginning to creep over him ; and at the close of the scene the Ghost speaks from under the ground.' The earliest change in this stage direction that I can find is in Schroeder's adaptation of the play for the Hamburg theatre, in 178 1. Here the scene is laid in ' A Graveyard with th4 Church in the background?

97.play: Hamlet: O all you host of heaven! O earth! what else?
notes: Coleridge: I remember nothing equal to this burst unless it be the first speech of Prometheus, in the Greek drama, after the exit of Vulcan and the two Afrite. But Shakespeare alone could have produced the vow of Hamlet to make his memory a blank of all maxims and generalized truths, followed immediately by the speaker noting down the generalized fact, line 113.

98.play: Hamlet: And shall I couple hell? Oh, fie! Hold, hold, my heart;

99.play: Hamlet: And you, my sinews, grow not instant old,
notes: Dyce (Gloss.): "Saws" means sayings, maxims.

100.play: Hamlet: But bear me stiffly up. Remember thee?
notes: Dyce (Gloss.): "Pressures"—impressions as of a seal; see III, ii, 23.

101.play: Hamlet: Ay, thou poor ghost, while memory holds a seat

102.play: Hamlet: In this distracted globe. Remember thee?

103.play: Hamlet: Yea, from the table of my memory

104.play: Hamlet: I'll wipe away all trivial fond records,

105.play: Hamlet: All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past,
notes: Collier (ed. 2): The (MS) adds "and perfidious." The two words, "pernicious" and "perfidious," looking similar, perhaps the old printer, having composed the first, fancied he had composed both.

106.play: Hamlet: That youth and observation copied there;

107.play: Hamlet: And thy commandment all alone shall live
notes: Farmer: "'See,—and in the midst of the sermon pulles out his tables in haste, as if he feared to loose that note.' — Hall, in his character of The Hypocrite."

108.play: Hamlet: Within the book and volume of my brain,
notes: Moberly: "Smile" refers to the king having recently done so when he called Hamlet his son.

109.play: Hamlet: Unmix'd with baser matter; yes, by heaven!

notes: Steevens: An allusion to the watch-word, given every day in military service.

111.play: Hamlet: O villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!

112.play: Hamlet: My tables, meet it is I set it down,

113.play: Hamlet: That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain;

114.play: Hamlet: At least I'm sure it may be so in Denmark. [Writing.]

115.play: Hamlet: So, uncle, there you are. Now to my word;

116.play: Hamlet: It is: 'Adieu, adieu! remember me.'

notes: Upton: He swears them on his sword, very soldier-like, agreeable to the ancient custom. Ammianus Marcellinus relates the same ceremony among the Huns.

122.play: Horatio [within]: Illo, ho, ho, my lord!

123.play: Hamlet: Hillo, ho, ho, boy! come, bird, come.

125.play: Marcellus: How is't, my noble lord?

128.play: Horatio: Good my lord, tell it.
notes: Clarendon: For this colloquial and familiar use, see III, ii, 3; III, ii, 117; IV, iii, 21-24; Antony and Cleopatra II, vii, 29.

129.play: Hamlet: No; you will reveal it.

130.play: Horatio: Not I, my lord, by heaven.

132.play: Hamlet: How say you, then; would heart of man once think it?

134.play: Both: Ay, by heaven, my lord.

135.play: Hamlet: There's ne'er a villain dwelling in all Denmark

136.play: Hamlet: But he's an arrant knave.
notes: Tschischwitz: If Shakespeare had wished to be historically correct, he would have made a Dane swear by St. Ansgarius.

137.play: Horatio: There needs no ghost, my lord, come from the grave

139.play: Hamlet: Why, right; you are i' the right;

140.play: Hamlet: And so, without more circumstance at all,

141.play: Hamlet: I hold it fit that we shake hands and part;

142.play: Hamlet: You, as your business and desire shall point you;

143.play: Hamlet: For every man hath business and desire,

144.play: Hamlet: Such as it is; and for my own poor part,

145.play: Hamlet: Look you, I'll go pray.

146.play: Horatio: These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.

147.play: Hamlet: I'm sorry they offend you, heartily;

149.play: Horatio: There's no offence, my lord.

150.play: Hamlet: Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio,
notes: Steevens: This word, as well as some of Hamlet's former exclamations, we find in The Malcontent, 1604.

151.play: Hamlet: And much offence too. Touching this vision here,

152.play: Hamlet: It is an honest ghost, that let me tell you;

153.play: Hamlet: For your desire to know what is between us,

154.play: Hamlet: O'ermaster't as you may. And now, good friends,

155.play: Hamlet: As you are friends, scholars, and soldiers,

156.play: Hamlet: Give me one poor request.

157.play: Horatio: What is't, my lord? we will.

158.play: Hamlet: Never make known what you have seen to-night

159.play: Both: My lord, we will not.
notes: Abbott: For instances of "of" following verbal nouns, see Abbott, § 178.

163.play: Marcellus: Nor I, my lord, in faith.
notes: Dyce (Gloss.): "Pioner" is a pioneer; generally soldiers who, on account of misconduct, had been degraded to the office.

165.play: Marcellus: We have sworn, my lord, already.

166.play: Hamlet: Indeed, upon my sword, indeed.

168.play: Hamlet: Ah, ha, boy! say'st thou so? art thou there, true-penny?—

169.play: Hamlet: Come on; you hear this fellow in the cellarage;

171.play: Horatio: Propose the oath, my lord.
notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 263): The inversion [by putting only a comma after "seen"] is anti-Shakespearian.

172.play: Hamlet: Never to speak of this that you have seen.
notes: Tschischwitz: The repetition of the oath, the shifting of the ground, and the Latin phrase are taken from the ceremonies of conjurers.

175.play: Hamlet: Hie et ubique? then we'll shift our ground.—

177.play: Hamlet: And lay your hands again upon my sword,

178.play: Hamlet: Never to speak of this that you have heard;

181.play: Hamlet: Well said, old mole! canst work i' the earth so fast?

182.play: Hamlet: A worthy pioner!—Once more remove, good friends.

183.play: Horatio: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!

184.play: Hamlet: And therefore as a stranger give it welcome.

185.play: Hamlet: There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio,

186.play: Hamlet: Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.

188.play: Hamlet: Here, as before, never, so help you mercy,

189.play: Hamlet: How strange or odd soe'er I bear myself,

190.play: Hamlet: As I perchance hereafter shall think meet

191.play: Hamlet: To put an antic disposition on,

192.play: Hamlet: That you, at such times seeing me, never shall,

193.play: Hamlet: With arms encumber'd thus, or this head-shake,

194.play: Hamlet: Or by pronouncing of some doubtful phrase,

195.play: Hamlet: As 'Well, well, we know,' or 'We could, an if we would,'

196.play: Hamlet: Or 'If we list to speak,' or 'There be, an if they might,'

197.play: Hamlet: Or such ambiguous giving out, to note

198.play: Hamlet: That you know aught of me; this not to do,
notes: Caldecott: The grammar here is defective and the construction embarrassed: "Swear here as before, never, that you never shall, by pronouncing some doubtful phrase or the like, [do aught] to mark or denote, &c."

199.play: Hamlet: So grace and mercy at your most need help you,

202.play: Hamlet: Rest, rest, perturbed spirit!—So, gentlemen,

203.play: Hamlet: With all my love I do commend me to you;

204.play: Hamlet: And what so poor a man as Hamlet is

205.play: Hamlet: May do, to express his love and friending to you,

206.play: Hamlet: God willing, shall not lack. Let us go in together;

207.play: Hamlet: And still your fingers on your lips, I pray.

208.play: Hamlet: The time is out of joint;—O cursed spite,

209.play: Hamlet: That ever I was born to set it right!—
notes: Seymour: Hamlet does not lament that the disjointed time is to be set right by him, but that he, whose duty it becomes by necessity to set the time right, should have been born. ---

210.play: Hamlet: Nay, come, let's go together. [Exeunt.]

1.play: Polonius: Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.
notes: Seymour: Hamlet does not lament that the disjointed time is to be set right by him, but that he, whose duty it of necessity becomes to set the time right, should have been born.

3.play: Polonius: You shall do marvellous wisely, good Reynaldo,
notes: For instances of 'shall' for will, see III, iv, 317; Macb. III, iv, 57, and Abbott, §315.
For instances of adjectives used as adverbs, see I, iii, 116; III, ii, 288, and Abbott, §1.

4.play: Before you visit him, to make inquiry
notes: Clarendon: Clarendon adopts the Qq reading, and justifies it on the thoroughly Shakespearian usage of various parts of speech as nouns, such as 'avouch,' I, i, 57; 'disclose,' III, i, 166. For many other examples, see Abbott, §451.

6.play: Reynaldo: My lord, I did intend it.

7.play: Polonius: Marry, well said, very well said. Look you, sir,
notes: Capell: Danske, for Denmark, occurs often in Albion's England.

8.play: Inquire me first what Danskers are in Paris,

9.play: And how, and who; what means, and where they keep;
notes: Dyce: To live, to dwell.

10.play: What company, at what expense; and finding

11.play: By this encompassment and drift of question
notes: Caldecott: Winding and circuitous course.

12.play: That they do know my son, come you more nearer
notes: For instances of double comparatives, see Abbott, §11. Clarendon: ‘Neere’ of F2 shows that the double comparative was growing obsolete in 1632. Keightly believes all difficulty to be removed by following Jennens’ reading. Moberly: By these natural and circuitous inquiries you will get nearer the point than you possibly could by a direct question. [Pol. repeats this same idea in lines 65, 66. For other instances of double comparatives, see III, ii, 291; III, iv, 157; V, ii, 121. Ed.]

13.play: Than your particular demands will touch it;
notes: See Abbott, §226, for instances of 'it' used indefinitely, as the object of a verb, without referring to anything previously mentioned, and seeming to indicate a pre-existing object in the mind of the person spoken of, 'or in the mind of the speaker, as in this instance,' Clarendon adds.

14.play: Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him,
notes: Delius: Assume the appearance of having some distant, &c.

15.play: As thus, 'I know his father and his friends,

16.play: And in part him.' Do you mark this, Reynaldo?

17.play: Reynaldo: Ay, very well, my lord.

18.play: Polonius: 'And in part him; but,' you may say, 'not well;

19.play: But if't be he I mean, he's very wild,

20.play: Addicted' so and so; and there put on him

21.play: What forgeries you please; marry, none so rank

22.play: As may dishonour him; take heed of that;

23.play: But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips
notes: Clarendon: Compare Oth. IV, i, 9. Perhaps Shakespeare had the other sense of the word in his mind, as in 2 Hen. IV: III, ii, 214: 'graft with crab-tree slip.'

24.play: As are companions noted and most known

notes: Delius: This qualifies ‘companions.’

This is bracketed by Warburton as 'an interpolation.' Johnson: A too diligent frequentation of the fencing-school, a resort of violent and lawless young men. Malone: I suppose it means piquing himself on his skill in the use of the sword, and consequently quarrelling and brawling. 'The cunning of Fencers [is now] applied to quarrelling.' — Gosson, Schoole of Abuse, 1579, p. 46, ed. Arber.

27.play: Polonius: Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, quarrelling,

28.play: Drabbing; you may go so far.

29.play: Reynaldo: My lord, that would dishonour him.

30.play: Polonius: Faith, no; as you may season it in the charge.
notes: See I, ii, 192.

31.play: You must not put another scandal on him,
notes: Theobald (Sh. Restored, p. 61), on the ground that there could be no second scandal without a first (and Polonius implies that 'Drabbing' is no scandal), conjectured an utter for 'another.' And this emendation was adopted by Han. Warb. Johns, and Elze. But Theobald, in his edition, withdrew it, because Shakespeare uses 'other' in the same way elsewhere; as in Rich. II: I, i, 33, and Macb. IV, iii, 90. Malone: That is, a very different and more scandalous failing: habitual incontinency. Moberly: A deeper kind of scandal; much as ἀλλὰς means ‘particularly,’ and ἀλλοδαπὸς, in the Odyssey, 'an out-of-the-way or foreign traveller.'

32.play: That he is open to incontinency;

33.play: That's not my meaning; but breathe his faults so quaintly
notes: Dyce: To utter, to speak; see also line 44.
Dyce: Ingeniously, cleverly, artfully.

34.play: That they may seem the taints of liberty,

35.play: The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind,

notes: Clarendon: Cotgrave has ‘Adomestiquer: To tame, reclaim, make gentle.’ A term of falconry.
Dyce: A wildness in untamed blood, to which all young men are liable.
For instances of monosyllabic exclamations taking the place of a whole foot, see Abbott, §482, and IV, vii, 60; 'O,' IV, iv, 65; III, i, 49.

39.play: Polonius: Wherefore should you do this?

notes: Dyce: A warranted, sanctioned, or approved artifice or device. Clarendon: The fetch of wit of the Qq is ‘a cunning contrivance,’ and makes as good sense as the reading of the Ff, with which compare ‘passages of proof,’ IV, vii, 113. In Lear, II, iv, 90, ‘fetches’ mean pretexts, excuses.
Caldecott: As having in his commerce with the world unavoidably contracted some small blemishes.

42.play: Polonius: Marry, sir, here's my drift,

43.play: And I believe it is a fetch of warrant;

44.play: You laying these slight sullies on my son,

45.play: As 'twere a thing a little soil'd i' the working,

47.play: Your party in converse, him you would sound,
notes: Clarendon: Conversation. See Oth. III, i, 40, where it is accented as here.
For instances where 'him' is put for he, by attraction to whom understood, for he whom, see Abbott, §208.

48.play: Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes

49.play: The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured

50.play: He closes with you in this consequence:
notes: Caldecott: Falls in with you into this conclusion.

51.play: ' Good sir,' or so, or 'friend,' or 'gentleman,'

52.play: According to the phrase or the addition
notes: See I, iv, 20; Macb. I, iii, 106.

55.play: Polonius: And then, sir, does he this,—he does,—what was I about to say? By the mass, I was about to say something; where did I leave?

56.play: Reynaldo: At 'closes in the consequence,' at 'friend or so,' and 'gentleman.'

57.play: Polonius: At 'closes in the consequence,' ay, marry;
notes: Clarendon: Leave off. So in 2 Hen. VI; III, ii, 333. [See III, iv, 66.]

58.play: He closes with you thus: 'I know the gentleman;
notes: Elze: For this unmistakable interpolation we are probably indebted to some actor who wished to repeat the laughable gestures which accompanied it.

59.play: I saw him yesterday, or t'other day,
notes: Clarendon: That is, by intoxication. One of the many euphemisms for 'drunk.'

60.play: Or then, or then, with such, or such, and, as you say,

61.play: There was he gaming, there o'ertook in's rouse,

62.play: There falling out at tennis; or perchance,

63.play: 'I saw him enter such a house of sale,'

64.play: Videlicet, a brothel, or so forth.

66.play: Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth;

67.play: And thus do we of wisdom and of reach,
notes: Clarendon: Far-sighted. See I, iv, 56. Compare ‘we of taste and feeling.’ — Love's Lab. Lost, IV, ii, 30. Abbott, §168: 'Of here means by means of.'

68.play: With windlasses and with assays of bias,
notes: Nares: Metaphorically, art and contrivance, subtleties; e.g. ‘Which, by slie drifts, and windlaces aloof, They brought about.’ — Mirror for Magistrates, p. 336. Windlaies is used by Fairfax, for sudden turns; whether he meant this word or another, is not quite clear: perhaps, rather, windings: — ‘The beauties faire of shepherd's daughters bold, With wanton windlaies runne, turne, play, and passe.’ — Tasso, xiv, 34. Hunter (ii, 226): Windlaces is used in a sense now forgotten. We find it in Golding's Ovid, the seventh book, the book in which Shakespeare was so well read: ‘— like a wily fox he runs not forth directly out, Nor makes a windlasse over all the champion fields about,’ &c. It is also used by Bishop Hacket. Edinburgh Review [Shakespearian Glossaries, July, 1869): In Shakespeare's day, windlace, literally, a winding, was used to express taking a circuitous course, fetching a compass, making an indirect advance, or, more colloquially, beating about the bush instead of going directly to a place or object; and in this sense it exactly harmonizes with the other phrase used by Polonius to express the same thing,—‘assays of bias,’—attempts in which, instead of going straight to the object, we seek to reach it by a curved or winding course, the bias gradually bringing the ball round to the Jack. Thus, in Golding's Ovid: ‘The winged God...Continued not directly forth, but gan me down to stoupe, And fetched a windlasse round about.’ Clarendon: Also Lily's Euphues and his England (ed. Arber), p. 270: ‘I now fetching a windlesse, that I myght better haue a shoote, was preuented with ready game.’

Clarendon: A metaphor from the game of bowls, in which the player does not aim at the Jack (or ‘mistress,’ as it was called in Shakespeare’s time) directly, but in a curve, so that the bias brings the ball round. 'Assays of bias' are therefore indirect attempts.
Clarendon: Indirect methods. We find out indirectly, says Polonius, what we wish to know directly. See Jul. Ca?s. IV, iii, 75.

70.play: So, by my former lecture and advice,

71.play: Shall you my son. You have me, have you not?

73.play: Polonius: God be wi' you; fare you well.
notes: See Macb. III, i, 43, or Walker (Vers. 228).

Tschischwitz: Although the double leave-taking is quite in keeping with the loquacity of Polonius, we are justified, nevertheless, in expecting a reply from the departing servant. I have therefore given the words 'God be wi' you' (which, by the contraction of with into 'wi',' express a certain condescension) to Polonius, and 'fare you well' to Reynaldo.
Dyce: Reynaldo has previously said 'Very good, my lord,' and he afterwards says, 'Well, my lord,' but the present speech is not therefore to be pointed 'Good, my lord.' Compare II, ii, 521.

75.play: Polonius: Observe his inclination in yourself.
notes: Johnson: Perhaps this means, in your own person, not by spies. Capell: 'In yourself' is put for—observe of yourself, or with your own eyes; for he had been lesson'd before to pick up his 'inclination' from others. C. (in Var. 1821): The temptations you feel, suspect in him. Caldecott: It seems no more than ‘of or by yourself,’ and as if the word 'in' had been altogether omitted. He was at first to discover Laertes's inclination by enquiry from others; but now to find them out by personal observation. Tschischwitz: I find it hard to persuade myself that 'in' is anything more than a misprint, which arose from the last syllable of the preceding word. A change of 'in' into then could be easily made except for the uniformity of the old copies. Clarendon: Possibly it means, Conform your own conduct to his inclinations.

77.play: Polonius: And let him ply his music.
notes: Clarke: Let him go on, to what tune he pleases; let him conduct himself in any style and at any rate he chooses. Hudson: Eye him sharply, but do it slyly, and let him fiddle his secrets all out. Vischer (Sh. Jahrbuch, ii, p. 149): Here we have the key to the whole scene. His son may gamble, drink, swear, quarrel, drab, enter houses of sale, videlicet, brothels, only—let him ply his music: true cavalier-breeding!

80.play: Polonius: How now, Ophelia! what's the matter?
notes: Moberly: There is a wonderfully fine contrast between the prolix slyness of Polonius's attempt to find out what had better be unknown, and the scene of distracting and passionate misery which shows how Hamlet's soul has been shattered by an unsought-for revelation.

81.play: Ophelia: O, my lord, my lord, I have been so affrighted!
notes: Eckhardt (Vorlesungen über Hamlet. Aarau, 1853, p. 96): The supposition that Hamlet went to Ophelia directly after the interview with the Ghost is incorrect, and for the following reasons: first, the interview between Polonius and Reynaldo implies that some little time has elapsed since the departure of Laertes for Paris; secondly, during this time Ophelia has returned Hamlet's letters, and denied him access; her father asks her, 'Have you given him any hard words of late?' The letter which Polonius reads to the King must, therefore, have belonged to a period before the opening of the drama. Ophelia had strictly obeyed her father's commands, and returned all Hamlet's letters. Thirdly, Polonius goes at once to the King, and yet, when he speaks to him of Hamlet, the King already knew of Hamlet's (feigned) insanity, and therefore must himself have seen the Prince before Ophelia saw him. Fourthly, between the close of the first act and the present scene, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern must have been summoned on account of Hamlet's changed demeanor, and of the King's suspicions which that demeanor had aroused.

82.play: Polonius: With what, i' the name of God?
notes: See Abbott, §275; and II, ii, 177; or Macb. I, ii, 43.

83.play: Ophelia: My lord, as I was sewing in my closet,
notes: Clarendon: A private apartment. Hence the King's private secretary was called 'clerk of the closet.' See III, ii, 315; and King John, IV, ii, 267.

84.play: Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbraced;
notes: Clarendon: Unfastened. Compare Jul. Cæs. I, iii, 48; and II, i, 262.

Cambridge Editors: Theobald reads loose on the authority, as he says, ‘of the elder Qq.’ It is not the reading of any of the first six, but of those of 1676, 1683, 1695, and 1703. Had Capell been aware of this, he would scarcly have designated Theobald's mistake as a 'downright falsehood.' Theobald at the time of writing his Sh. Restored knew of no Quarto earlier than that of 1637 (Sh. Rest. p. 70), and it is just possible that some copy of this edition (Q6) from which that of 1676 was printed may have had the reading 'loose.' [The Cam. Edd. refer to a note on III, iv, 59, where they give two different readings in two different copies of Q4, ‘a heaven-kissing’ in Ingleby's copy, and ‘a heaue, a kissing,’ in Capell's copy. This variation in copies of the same date has long been known to exist in the older Qq, but, I confess, I was not prepared to find much variation in later Qq of the same date. In no less than twenty-four instances, however, I have found that my copy of Q4 70 differs from that of the Cam. Edd., as recorded in their notes. Ed.]

Keightley completed the rhythm of this line by the insertion of in after ‘comes.’ Abbott, §478, makes the second syllable of 'horrors' a foot by itself on the principle that ‘er [or or] final seems to have been sometimes pronounced with a kind of "burr," which produced the effect of an additional syllable.’ A process which neither my tongue nor my imagination can compass. Why not let Ophelia's strong emotion shudderingly fill up the gap?

85.play: No hat upon his head; his stockings foul'd,

86.play: Ungarter'd, and down-gyved to his ancle;
notes: Nares: It was the regular amorous etiquette, in the reign of Elizabeth, for a man professing himself deeply in love to assume a certain negligence in dress. His garters, in particular, were not to be tied up. See As You Like It, III, ii, 398.
Heath: Gives the true definition of 'down-gyved': fallen down to the ancle, after the fashion of gyves, or fetters.

87.play: Pale as his shirt; his knees knocking each other;

88.play: And with a look so piteous in purport
notes: Walker: Pronounce 'purport,' not 'piteous.'

89.play: As if he had been loosed out of hell

90.play: To speak of horrors, he comes before me.

notes: See I, ii, 217.

92.play: Ophelia: My lord, I do not know,

93.play: But truly I do fear it.

95.play: Ophelia: He took me by the wrist, and held me hard;

96.play: Then goes he to the length of all his arm,

97.play: And with his other hand thus o'er his brow,

98.play: He falls to such perusal of my face
notes: Clarendon: Examination. See Rom. & Jul. V, iii, 74; Rich. II: III, iii, 53; Tro. & Cres. IV, v, 232. [Also, Ham. IV, vii, 137.]

99.play: As he would draw it. Long stay'd he so;
notes: Abbott, §507: As ed is pronounced after i and u, so it might be after y in ‘stayed,’ but the effect would be painful. The pause after 'it' must supply the extra syllable.
Tschischwitz: A verbal substantive; is made is understood.

100.play: At last, a little shaking of mine arm,
notes: Boswell: This is not, I think, all the body, but the breast. Pettorata, in Florio, is explained, ‘a shock against the breast or bulk.’ [Dyce (Gloss.) also cites this definition of Pettorata from Florio, but neither the word nor definition is in my copy of Florio, 1598. Malone cites R. of Lucrece, 467, ‘her heart Beating her bulk,’ and Rich. III: I, iv, 40, ‘my panting bulk,’ but defines 'bulk' by 'all the body.' Ed.] Singer: 'The Bulke or breast of a man.' — Baret's Alvearie. Dyce (Gloss.): 'The Bulke of the bodie. Tronc, buste.' — Cotgrave. Clarendon also cites Cotgrave: 'Buste, the whole bulke or bodie of a man, from his face to his middle.' [Minsheu gives: 'Pechuguera, the whole bulke of the breast.' Ed.]

101.play: And thrice his head thus waving up and down,

102.play: He raised a sigh so piteous and profound
notes: Alienation of mind, madness. See III, i, 160; III, iv, 74; 138, 139; Macb. III, ii, 22; IV, iii, 170.

103.play: As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
notes: Miles (Review of Hamlet, p. 28): We are not permitted to see Hamlet in this ecstasy of love, but what a picture! How he must have loved her, that love should bring him to such a pass!—his knees knocking each other!—knees that had firmly followed a beckoning ghost! There is more than the love of forty thousand brothers in that hard grasp of the wrist,—in that long gaze at arm's length,—in the force that might, but will not, draw her nearer! And never a word from this king of words! His first great silence,—the second is death!

104.play: And end his being; that done, he lets me go;

105.play: And with his head over his shoulder turn'd

106.play: He seem'd to find his way without his eyes;

107.play: For out o' doors he went without their help,

108.play: And to the last bended their light on me.

109.play: Polonius: Come, go with me; I will go seek the king.

110.play: This is the very ecstasy of love;

112.play: And leads the will to desperate undertakings,

113.play: As oft as any passion under heaven

114.play: That does afflict our natures. I am sorry,—

115.play: What, have you given him any hard words of late?

116.play: Ophelia: No, my good lord, but, as you did command,

117.play: I did repel his letters, and denied

notes: Steevens: To destroy. Nares: For has here its negative power. Clarendon: Like the German ver, it is also sometimes intensive, as in ‘forgive,’ ‘forwearied,’ ‘forspent.’ [It is so used in the past participle of this very verb so Mid. N, D. V, i, 381, 'with weary task fordone.'—Ed.]

119.play: Polonius: That hath made him mad.

120.play: I am sorry that with better heed and judgement
notes: For instances of adjectives used as nouns, see Abbott, §5.

121.play: I had not quoted him. I fear'd he did but trifle
notes: For uses of 'will' to mean 'passion’ or ‘strong faculty,’ see Abbott, §366.

122.play: And meant to wreck thee; but beshrew my jealousy!
notes: Johnson: This is not the remark of a weak man. The vice of age is too much suspicion. Men long accustomed to the wiles of life cast commonly beyond themselves, let their cunning go farther than reason can attend it. This is always the fault of a little mind, made artful by long commerce with the world. Moberly: To forecast more than we ought for our own interests. Clarendon: To 'contrive,' 'design,' 'plan.' Compare Spenser's Fairy Queen, i, 5,12: ‘Of all attonce he cast avengd to be.’ Cotgrave translates Fr. minuter, ‘to devise, cast, or lay the first project of a designe.’
Clarendon: Accented on the second syllable in Macb. I, v, 42.

123.play: By heaven, it is as proper to our age
notes: Theobald preferred speed of the Ff, in the sense either of success, fortune (frequent in Shakespeare), or of celerity.
Clarendon: Appropriate. Compare 2 Hen. IV: I, iii, 32.

124.play: To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
notes: M. Mason: Invariably used by Shakespeare in the sense of to observe. Malone: 'Quoter, To quote, or marke in the margent, to note by the way.'—Cotgrave. Dyce: To note, to mark,—formerly pronounced, and often written, cote. See Rom. & Jul. I, iv, 31.

125.play: As it is common for the younger sort

126.play: To lack discretion. Come, go we to the king;

127.play: This must be known; which, being kept close, might move
notes: Warburton: That is, this must be made known to the King, for (being kept secret) the hiding of Hamlet's love might occasion more mischief to us from him and the Queen, than the uttering or revealing of it will occasion hate and resentment from Hamlet. Heath: The concealment of it may be attended with consequences productive of greater calamity than the displeasure can possibly be with which the disclosing it may be received. Caldecott: At the close of an act, or when the scene is shifted, and there is a pause in the action of the drama, it was the usage of our dramatists, down to the middle of the last century, not simply to divert attention from the main object, as here, by the introduction of a couplet or rhymes, but to make the subject of such couplet foreign altogether to the interests of the drama, an unconnected flourish, and that, not unfrequently, a labored and florid simile. Such a custom in Shakespeare, so far from being what Warburton calls it, was the very opposite of 'affectation;' not to have done it occasionally would have been an affectation of singularity. Clarendon: In the couplets which conclude scenes the sense is frequently sacrificed to the rhyme. The sense here seems to be — Hamlet's mad conduct might cause more grief if it were hidden than the revelation of his love for Ophelia would cause hatred, i.e. on the part of the King and Queen. Yet the Queen afterwards expresses her approval of the match, III, i, 38. Compare also, V, i, 231-234. Tschischwitz cannot persuade himself that the author of the Sonnets and of Venus & Adonis could have composed lines so faulty in logic and style as these, and he therefore thinks that even sticklers for the authorized text will pardon him for changing line 119 into ‘More grief to him, than hate to us their love.’ He also marks 'Ophelia exit' after line 126.

128.play: More grief to hide than hate to utter love.

1.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern!
notes: Thornbury (N. & Q. 5 Aug. 1871): Rosencrantz] A Danish nobleman of this name attended the Danish ambassador into England on the ascension of James I. [Steevens says it was an ambassador. Ed.]

2.play: Moreover that we much did long to see you,
notes: Moberly: Moreover that] Over and above that we longed to see you. On the other hand, "more above," in line 131, means "moreover." Clarendon: Besides that. Hudson: I do not recollect another instance of these words thus used.

3.play: The need we have to use you did provoke

4.play: Our hasty sending. Something have you heard

5.play: Of Hamlet's transformation; so call it,
notes: transformation] On the pronunciation of the final ion as a dissyllabic, see Walker, Vers. 230; Abbott, § 479, and V, ii, 217.

6.play: Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man
notes: 6: Moberly: Sith] The oldest meaning of this difficult word may be seen from the Fairy Queen (iii, io, 33), "he humbly thanked him a thousand sith," literally, "a thousand steps" (Matzner, i, p. 390 [=410?]). Hence, apparently, 'sithen the fathers died,' in Wickliffe's Bible, means "from the time when;" the preposition being omitted, as in many English phrases even now. Then come the absolutes "sith, sithence, since," as in line 12 below. Lastly, the adverb becomes a causative conjunction; on the principle that "propter hoc" may be practically, though loosely, expressed by "post hoc." That is, "Sin thou are righteous judge" means "following on the fact that thou art a righteous judge." Clarendon: Marsh [Lectures on the English Language, pp. 584-586] says, that in the latter half of the sixteenth century "good authors established a distinction between the forms, and used sith only as a logical word, an illative, while sithence and since, whether as prepositions or as adverbs, remained mere narrative words confined to the signification of time after." Sh., it is clear, did not observe this distinction, whether we take the quartos or the folios to represent his exact text. [See IV, iv, 45.].

7.play: Resembles that it was. What it should be,

8.play: More than his father's death, that thus hath put him

9.play: So much from the understanding of himself,

10.play: I cannot dream of: I entreat you both,

11.play: That, being of so young days brought up with him,
notes: Abbott, § 167: "Of," applied to time, in cases like the present, means from. So still "of late." Compare "Of long time he had bewitched them."—Acts, viii, 11. [See also Matzner, ii,

12.play: And sith so neighbour'd to his youth and havior,
notes: Corson: humour] There is more force in this word than in haviour. It must be taken in its earlier sense of temper of mind, disposition.

13.play: That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court
notes: That] Delius That' is redundant.
rest] Caldecott: That you please to reside.

14.play: Some little time: so by your companies
notes: [Text note: "companies" — See I, i, 173.]

15.play: To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather,

16.play: So much as from occasion you may glean,

17.play: Whether aught, to us unknown, afflicts him thus,
notes: [Text note: "Whether" — To be pronounced as a monosyllable. See Walker, Vers. 103; and Abbott, § 466; Macb. I, iii, in; Ham. Ill, ii, 193.]
"certain players. We o'er-raught (overtook, overpassed) on the way."

18.play: That, open'd, lies within our remedy.

19.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : Good gentlemen, he hath much talk'd of you;

20.play: And sure I am two men there are not living

21.play: To whom he more adheres. If it will please you

22.play: To show us so much gentry and good will
notes: Warburton: gentry] Complaisance. Singer: "Gentlemanlinesse, or gentrie, kindelinesse, naturall goodnesse. Generositas." — Baret's Alvearie. See V, ii, 109.

208: [Warburton, Johnson, Malone, Whiter, Coleridge, Caldecott, Mitford, Knight, Collier, Delius, Dyce, Maginn, White, Staunton, Heussi, Tschischwitz, Hudson, Moberly, Clarendon, Corson, and others discuss the difficulty and textual crux of "good kissing carrion." Warburton emends to "God, kissing carrion," making sense of a metaphysical point; Johnson calls it a noble emendation; others, including Malone and White, explain the printed text as referring to the sun's role in putrefaction, and its metaphorical bearing on Ophelia and on honesty in the world. Corson, finally, says the problem is caused by mistaking "kissing" for the present participle, instead of the verbal noun, so "good kissing carrion" means "carrion good for kissing (by the sun)."]

23.play: As to expend your time with us awhile,

24.play: For the supply and profit of our hope,
notes: Caldecott: supply and profit] In aid and furtherance. Hudson: The feeding and realizing.
Johnson: hope] That the hope which your arrival has made may be completed by the desired effect.

25.play: Your visitation shall receive such thanks

28.play: Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,
notes: Abbott, § 174: of] "Of" here means over; as in line 283 it means on, and in III, ii, 59, about.

29.play: Put your dread pleasures more into command

notes: Delius: But] This "but" is redundant; there is no opposition here to what Rosencrantz has said. It is needless to retain it for the sake of rhythm, because the time of an extra syllable is made up by the pause between the speeches.

32.play: And here give up ourselves, in the full bent
notes: Johnson (Much Ado, IV, i, 188): bent] "Bent" is used by Sh. for the utmost degree of any passion or mental quality. The expression is derived from archery; the bow has its bent when it is drawn as far as it can be. [See Ham. III, ii, 387.]

33.play: To lay our service freely at your feet,

35.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.

36.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz:

37.play: And I beseech you instantly to visit

38.play: My too much changed son. Go, some of you,

39.play: And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.

40.play: GUILDENSTERN : Heavens make our presence and our practises
notes: Clarendon: Heavens] Compare Ant. & Cleo. I, ii, 64.

43.play: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and some Attendants

45.play: LORD POLONIUS : The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,

47.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Thou still hast been the father of good news.
notes: [Text note: still] See I, i, 122.

48.play: LORD POLONIUS : Have I, my lord? I assure my good liege,

49.play: I hold my duty, as I hold my soul,

50.play: Both to my God and to my gracious king:
notes: Knight: and] The reading of the Ff means that Polonius holds that his duty to his king is an obligation as imperative as his duty to his God, to whom his soul is subject. Dyce (Strictures, &c., 187) truly says that the attempts to explain the error, one, of the Ff, have proved unsuccessful. HUDSON: I hold my duty both to my God and to my king, as I do my soul.

51.play: And I do think, or else this brain of mine

52.play: Hunts not the trail of policy so sure
notes: Johnson: trail] The course of an animal pursued by the scent.

53.play: As it hath used to do, that I have found

54.play: The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.

55.play: KING CLAUDIUS : O, speak of that; that do I long to hear.

56.play: LORD POLONIUS : Give first admittance to the ambassadors;
notes: Moberly: first] Thus Polonius gains the opportunity of studying a brief and pointed exordium, the only fault in which is its being altogether needless and misplaced.

57.play: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
notes: Johnson: fruit] The dessert after the meat. Caldecott: By news must be meant the talk or leading topic at, &c. Hunter (ii, 227): The Ff may suggest the true reading: nuts. We still say, "It will be nuts to him," where a person has to hear something that will please him. The allusion to a banquet is kept up. Tschischwitz adopts this emendation of Hunter's.

58.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.

60.play: KING CLAUDIUS : He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found
notes: White: Gertrude] This smacks less of the honeymoon than the text of the Ff.

61.play: The head and source of all your son's distemper.
notes: Caldecott: main] The chief point. See Tro. & Cres. II, iii, 273. "These flaws, Are to the main as inconsiderable," &c. — Par. Reg. iv, 454. Staunton: An ellipsis, — in being understood: — "no other but in the main." Clarendon: "Main" is used without a substantive following in 2 Hen. VI: I, i, 208.

62.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : I doubt it is no other but the main;

63.play: His father's death, and our o'erhasty marriage.

64.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Well, we shall sift him.

65.play: Re-enter POLONIUS, with VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS

66.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Welcome, my good friends!
notes: Walker (ii, 254, Omissions in Consequence of Absorption): [Welcome] He is addressing the ambassadors for the first time after their return from Norway. I think the occasion absolutely demands, "Welcome home!" &c. And [thus it is] in line 85.

67.play: Say, Voltimand, what from our brother Norway?

68.play: VOLTIMAND : Most fair return of greetings and desires.
notes: Delius: desires] The kind wishes for the health of the Norwegian king.
Caldecott: first] Audience, or opening of our business. Clarendon: At the first expression of the ambassadors' request.

69.play: Upon our first, he sent out to suppress

70.play: His nephew's levies; which to him appear'd

71.play: To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack;

72.play: But, better look'd into, he truly found
notes: Clarendon: truly] This adverb belongs in sense to "was," not to "found." See Mid. N. D. I, i, 126.

73.play: It was against your highness: whereat grieved,
notes: Delius: It] This, as well as "look'd into," refers to "levies," but the singular is used through attraction to the nearer noun: "preparation."

74.play: That so his sickness, age and impotence
notes: [Text note: "sends"] For ellipsis of nominative, see Abbott, § 399; and III, i, 8.

75.play: Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests

76.play: On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys;

77.play: Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine

78.play: Makes vow before his uncle never more

79.play: To give the assay of arms against your majesty.
notes: [Text note: "assay of arms"] Proof, trial. See "assay of art," Macb. IV, iii, 143.

80.play: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,

81.play: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,
notes: [Text note: "three thousand"] Theobald preferred the Qq because the larger sum seems a much more suitable gift from a king to his own nephew than so poor a pittance as three thousand crowns. Heath adduces in favor of the Ff the greater commercial value of money in those earlier ages, and thinks it probable that in the poor kingdom of Norway, in Hamlet's time, the king's whole revenue might scarce amount to so large a sum. Hunter (ii, 228): The reading of Qx is one proof, amongst others, either that the editors of Fx did not disdain the assistance of Qx, imperfect as it is, or that Qx has preserved readings which the editors of Fx had other reasons for knowing to be genuine.
Ritson: fee] The king gave his nephew a feud, or fee (in land), of that yearly value.

82.play: And his commission to employ those soldiers,

83.play: So levied as before, against the Polack:

84.play: With an entreaty, herein further shown,

86.play: That it might please you to give quiet pass

87.play: Through your dominions for this enterprise,

88.play: On such regards of safety and allowance
notes: Clarendon: safety and allowance] Terms securing the safety of the country and regulating the passage of the troops through it.

90.play: KING CLAUDIUS : It likes us well;
notes: Abbott (§ 297): It likes] An abundance of impersonal verbs is a mark of an early stage in a language, denoting that a speaker has not yet arrived so far in development as to trace his own actions and feelings to his own agency. There are many more impersonal verbs in Early English than in Elizabethan, and many more in Elizabethan than in modern English. See "Well be (it) with you," II, ii, 362, III. iv, 173; V, ii, 63. Matzner (iii, 174) gives the same phrase: "It likes us well," from King John, II, i, 533, with the following explanation: "The dative in Germanic verbs passes completely into the accusative where the consciousness of the language abandons the substitute for the dative by the periphrasis with to." ["Zounds! I was never so bethumped with words since first I called my brother's father, dad."—Ed.]

91.play: And at our more consider'd time well read,
notes: Caldecott: consider'd] When we have more time for considering. For Instances of an indefinite and apparently not passive use of passive participles, see Abbott, § 374.

92.play: Answer, and think upon this business.
notes: Anon. (Misc. Obs. 1752, p. 19): Answer, and think upon] The king is here made to say that he would give an answer to an affair before he had considered it. Read: "And think upon and answer to, this business." [See Hanmer, in Textual Notes.]

93.play: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour:
notes: [Text note: "well-took"] The reading of F3F3F4 suggested to Theobald (Sh. Rest. p. 191) well-luck'd as passing a sort of compliment on the address, skill, and good-fortune of Cor. and Volt. But he did not repeat the conjecture in his edition.

94.play: Go to your rest; at night we'll feast together:

97.play: LORD POLONIUS : This business is well ended.
notes: Johnson: Polonius is a man bred in courts, exercised in business, stored with observation, confident in his eloquence, and declining into dotage. His mode of oratory is truly represented as designed to ridicule the practice of those times, of prefaces that made no introduction, and of method that embarrassed rather than explained. This part of his character is accidental, the rest is natural. Such a man is positive and confident, because he knows that his mind was once strong, and knows not that it is become weak. Such a man excels in general principles, but fails in the particular application. He is knowing in retrospect, and ignorant in foresight. While he depends upon his memory, and can draw from his repositories of knowledge, he utters weighty sentences, and gives useful counsel; but as the mind in its enfeebled state cannot be kept long busy and intent, the old man is subject to sudden dereliction of his faculties; he loses the order of his ideas, and entangles himself in his own thoughts, till he recovers the leading principle, and falls again into his former train. This idea of dotage encroaching upon wisdom will solve all the phenomena of the character of Polonius. Caldecott: Nothing can be more easily conceivable or intelligible than the "idea of dotage encroaching upon wisdom"; but does this apply to Polonius? To be extinguished, talent or faculty must first have existence. Now we have nothing that directly goes to establish the fact of his having at any time a clear and commanding intellect. Almost everything has, on the contrary, an opposite bearing; for the very quality relied upon by Dr Johnson appears to us to be that which most strongly indicates imbecility of mind, viz. having the memory stored with sage rules and maxims, fit for every turn and occasion, without the faculty of making effective use of them upon any. In Polonius's general conduct, unmixed folly or dotage is visible at every turn. Moberly: In estimating this character we should do well to remember that the use of language like that of Polonius would not in Shakespeare's euphuistic days argue the complete folly that it would at the present time. [See also I, iii, 59. Ed.]

98.play: My liege, and madam, to expostulate
notes: Caldecott: expostulate] To show by discussion, to put the pros and cons, to answer demands upon the question. "Pausanias had now opportunity to visit her and to expostulate the favorable deceit, whereby she had caused his jealousie."—Stanley's Aurore, 1650, p. 44. Hunter (ii, 228): "Expostulate" is of rare occurrence. It occurs in A Brief Relation of the Shipwreck of Henry May, 1593, incorporated in Captain Smith's book on Virginia: "How these isles came by the name of the Bermudas, ... I will not expostulate, nor trouble your patience with these uncertain antiquities," p. 172. It means, to inquire, and when it is an inquiry from a superior in a state of displeasure, we get at once to what is the present signification of the world. Thus, in the manuscript book of Anecdotes collected by Sir Nicholas L'Estrange, there is one, No. 77, in which the master of the house, hearing a noise and disturbance, "comes and expostulates the cause." Clarendon: So in Two Gent. III, i, 251. Sh. also uses the word in its modern and legitimate sense.

99.play: What majesty should be, what duty is,
notes: Johnson (Note on line 382): wit] "Wit" was not in Shakespeare's time taken either for imagination or acuteness, or both together, but for understanding, for the faculty by which we apprehend and judge. Those who wrote of the human mind distinguished its primary powers into wit and will. STAUNTON: Wisdom. Clarendon: Knowledge. So Mer. of Ven. II, i,

100.play: Why day is day, night night, and time is time,
notes: Walker (Vers. 66): flourishes] A dissyllable.

101.play: Were nothing but to waste night, day and time.

102.play: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,

103.play: And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,

104.play: I will be brief: your noble son is mad:

105.play: Mad call I it; for, to define true madness,
notes: Moberly: Mad call I it] "It is of no use to explain how?" This shrewd remark is one of many that Polonius draws from his repositories of knowledge, and from that former wisdom on which dotage is rapidly encroaching.

106.play: What is't but to be nothing else but mad?

108.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : More matter, with less art.

109.play: LORD POLONIUS : Madam, I swear I use no art at all.
notes: Delius: art] The Queen uses "art" in reference to Polonius's stilted style; the latter uses it as opposed to truth and nature.

110.play: That he is mad, 'tis true: 'tis true 'tis pity;

111.play: And pity 'tis 'tis true: a foolish figure;

112.play: But farewell it, for I will use no art.

113.play: Mad let us grant him, then: and now remains
notes: [Text note: and now] For ellipses of there, see Abbott, § 404.

114.play: That we find out the cause of this effect,

115.play: Or rather say, the cause of this defect,

116.play: For this effect defective comes by cause:

117.play: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.
notes: [Text note: Perpend] Like "gather and surmise," this is used in accordance with Polonius's pedantic style. See As You Like It, III, ii, 69.

118.play: I have a daughter--have while she is mine--

119.play: Who, in her duty and obedience, mark,
notes: Alfred Roffe (N. & Q. 5 Oct. 1861) gives a list of no less than nine metrical and musical adaptations of this letter of Hamlet's. One of them, in date about 1800, "Composed for and dedicated to Miss Abrams by Michael Kelly," is as follows: "Doubt (O most beautified), that the stars are fire, Doubt (my soul's idol), that the sun doth move, Doubt that eternal Truth may prove a liar, But, sweet Ophelia, never doubt I love. My mind no skill in these fond numbers owns, Yet these declare I love thee best, most best, And though no Muses reckon up my groans, These lines may shelter in thy snowy breast.

Theobald objected to [beautified], because of its two meanings, viz. artificial and natural beauty; the first would be manifestly inappropriate here, and the second Sh. has used in Two Gent. IV, i, 55, and would not, therefore, here call it a "vile phrase." He therefore substituted beatified, which is less of an anticlimax than "beautified," after "Celestial and soul's idol," and which, moreover, would be the more likely to excite the Roman Catholic Polonius to anger, since it is almost peculiarly applied to the Virgin Mary. Capell (i, 130) prefers beatified, because of "its concordance with 'celestial' and 'idol,' and because the passage demands it, which is certainly verse." Accordingly, he reads lines 119 to 122, inclusive, as verse, dividing at "idol" (which, metri gratis, he reads "fair idol"), "Ophelia," "beautified" (which he reads "that beatify'd"), "these." Johnson: "Beautified" seems to be a vile phrase for the ambiguity of its meaning. Steevens: Nash dedicates his Christ's Tears over Jerusalem, 1594, "To the most beautified lady, the lady Elizabeth Carey." Nares: A common word in those times, particularly in the addresses of letters. The examples wherein a person is said to be "beautified" with various endowments seem hardly apposite. Caldecott: That is, accomplished, "metricall speach ... by Art bewtified and adorned, and brought far from the primitiue rudenesse."—Puttenham's Arte of English Poesie, 1589 [p. 39, ed. Arber]. DYCE (Gloss.): By "beautified" (which, however "vile a phrase," is common enough in our early writers) I believe Hamlet meant beautiful, and not accomplished.

120.play: Hath given me this: now gather, and surmise.
notes: Corson: Thus] It would seem that the first "these" in the Ff is right, the second being a mere repetition for emphasis; so that all that is wanting in the F is a colon after "heare." "These in her excellent white bosom, these:" The expression is evidently directive or optative, and given as an introduction to "Doubt thou, the Starres are, etc." The oddness in the letter, as is shown by the subscription. Malone: I have never met with "these" both at the beginning and the end of the superscription of letters.

Abbott, § 159: In] "In," like the kindred preposition on (Chaucer uses "in a hill" for "on a hill"), was used with verbs of motion as well as rest. We still say "he fell in love," &c. See V, ii, 70. See Storrffrich, Appendix, Vol. II.

122.play: 'To the celestial and my soul's idol, the most

124.play: That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; 'beautified' is

125.play: a vile phrase: but you shall hear. Thus:

127.play: 'In her excellent white bosom, these, & c.'
notes: [Text note: bosom] Steevens (Two Gent. III. i, 250): Women anciently had a pocket in the fore part of their stays, in which they not only carried love-letters and love-tokens, but even their money and materials for needle-work.

128.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : Came this from Hamlet to her?
notes: Delius: reckon] To number metrically, or scan.

129.play: LORD POLONIUS : Good madam, stay awhile; I will be faithful.
notes: Caldecott: to him] That is, belongs to, obeys his impulse; so long as he is a "sensible, warm motion," Meas. for Meas. III, i, 120. Clarendon: Hamlet's letter is written in the affected language of euphuism. Compare Cym. V, v, 253.'
Clarke: doubt] In the first three lines "doubt" is used in the sense of have a misgiving, have a half-belief, and in the fourth line, in the sense of disbelieve.
Johnson: more above] Moreover, besides.

132.play: Doubt that the sun doth move;

133.play: Doubt truth to be a liar;

135.play: 'O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers;

136.play: I have not art to reckon my groans: but that

137.play: I love thee best, O most best, believe it. Adieu.

139.play: this machine is to him, HAMLET.'

140.play: This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me,

141.play: And more above, hath his solicitings,

142.play: As they fell out by time, by means and place,
notes: Nares: table-book] The same as table; memorandum-book.
154: Clarendon: winking] Connivance, as in Hen. V: V, ii, 332. In Cym. II, iv, 89, "two winking Cupids" mean two blind Cupids, two Cupids with their eyes shut. So Acts, xvii, 30.

144.play: KING CLAUDIUS : But how hath she

146.play: LORD POLONIUS : What do you think of me?

147.play: KING CLAUDIUS : As of a man faithful and honourable.

148.play: LORD POLONIUS : I would fain prove so. But what might you think,

149.play: When I had seen this hot love on the wing--

150.play: As I perceived it, I must tell you that,

151.play: Before my daughter told me--what might you,

152.play: Or my dear majesty your queen here, think,

153.play: If I had play'd the desk or table-book,
notes: Malone: play'd the desk or table-book] The first line may mean, if I had locked up this secret in my own breast, as closely as it were confined in a desk or table-book. Moberly paraphrases this same line: If I had just minuted the matter down in my own mind.

154.play: Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,

155.play: Or look'd upon this love with idle sight;

156.play: What might you think? No, I went round to work,
notes: Steevens: round] Roundly, without reserve, as in III, i, 183; III, iv, 5. Caldecott: As here used, it cannot be more correctly interpreted than by the reverse of its literal meaning, i.e. without circuity. In this sense, and senses nearly allied to it, this word is used with great latitude. Dyce (Gloss.) gives eight different uses of round. Clarendon: The adjective is here used for the adverb, as in Bacon's Essay, vi: "A shew of fearfulnesse, which in any businesse doth spoile the feathers, of round flying up to the mark." Abbott, § 159: In] "In," like the kindred preposition on (Chaucer uses "in a hill" for "on a hill"), was used with verbs of motion as well as rest. We still say "he fell in love," &c. See V, ii, 70. See Storrffrich, Appendix, Vol. II.

157.play: And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:

158.play: 'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star;
notes: For the use of the prefix be-, see Abbott, § 438.

Boswell: star] "Out of thy star" is "placed above thee by fortune." We have "fortune's star," I, iv, 32. Collier: "Star" is probably to be taken as destiny. Singer: In Twelfth Night, II, v, 156, we have "in my stars I am above thee." White: Sphere is at once a plausible reading and a gloss. Staunton: Lord Hamlet is a prince beyond the influence of the star which governs your fortunes. Bailey (ii, 6): Substitute O for t, and you have "out of thy soar." It is not to be concealed that Sh. does not elsewhere employ soar as a noun.

159.play: This must not be:' and then I precepts gave her,
notes: Malone: prescripts] He had ordered, charged, Ophelia to lock herself up from Hamlet; see I, iii, 135.

160.play: That she should lock herself from his resort,

161.play: Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.

162.play: Which done, she took the fruits of my advice;
notes: Johnson: fruits] She took the fruits of advice, when she obeyed advice; the advice was then made fruitful.

163.play: And he, repulsed--a short tale to make--

164.play: Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,
notes: Warburton: sadness, fast, watch, weakness, lightness] The ridicule of this character is here admirably sustained. He would not only be thought to have discovered this intrigue by his own sagacity, but to have remarked all the stages of Hamlet's disorder, from his sadness to his raving, as regularly as his physician could have done; when all the while the madness was only feigned. The humor of this is exquisite from a man who tells us, with a confidence peculiar to small politicians, that he could find: "Where truth was hid, though it were hid indeed Within the centre."

165.play: Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,
notes: Caldecott: watch] A sleepless state.

166.play: Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,

167.play: Into the madness wherein now he raves,
notes: Clarke: madness] Sh. intended Hamlet should be deeply moved by Ophelia's unexplained repulse of him, coming immediately upon the shock he receives from the Ghost's revelation, and he seizes upon the one as affording apparent cause for his disturbance of mind arising out of the other, and by which he wishes to be believed to have been seized.
Abbott, § 240: all we] A feeling of the unemphatic nature of the nominatives we and they prevents us from saying "all we." [For another instance of a transposed pronoun, see V, ii, 14. Ed.]
Delius: for] The relative which must be supplied from the foregoing "wherein."

169.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Do you think 'tis this?

170.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : It may be, very likely.

171.play: LORD POLONIUS : Hath there been such a time--I'd fain know that--

172.play: That I have positively said 'Tis so,'

174.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Not that I know.

175.play: LORD POLONIUS : [Pointing to his head and shoulder]

176.play: Take this from this, if this be otherwise:

177.play: If circumstances lead me, I will find

178.play: Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed

180.play: KING CLAUDIUS : How may we try it further?

181.play: LORD POLONIUS : You know, sometimes he walks four hours together
