notes: Delius: muddied . . . unwholesome] These refer primarily to the blood, and then, with which Sh. here connects them, to the mood of the people. Dyce (ed. ii) reads mudded, as he does also in All's Well, V, ii, 4.

93.play: Thick and unwholesome in their thoughts and whispers,

94.play: For good Polonius' death; and we have done but greenly,
notes: Johnson: greenly] Unskilfully, with greenness, without maturity of judgement.

95.play: In hugger-mugger to inter him: poor Ophelia
notes: Steevens: hugger-mugger] Sh. probably took the expression from North's Plutarch, p. 999, ed. 1631 [p. 121, ed. Skeat]: 'Antonius thinking good .... that his bodie should be honorably buried, and not in hugger-mugger.' Malone: Its meaning is seen in Florio's Diet.: Dinascoso, secretly; hiddenly, in hugger-mugger. [See Wheatley's Diet. of Reduplicated Words.]

96.play: Divided from herself and her fair judgment,
notes: Tschischwitz: Divided] Compare V, ii, 221.

97.play: Without the which we are pictures, or mere beasts:

98.play: Last, and as much containing as all these,

99.play: Her brother is in secret come from France;

100.play: Feeds on his wonder, keeps himself in clouds,
notes: Clarendon: wonder] The mysterious death of Pol. filled his son with doubt and amazement.

Theobald (Nichols's Lit. Hist, ii, 575): in clouds] Thirlby has conjectured inclosed, i.e. private, close in his apartment, and cites IV, vii, 130, in confirmation. But change is needless; the text means: 'to be reserved and mysterious in his conduct.' Caldecott: At lofty distance and seclusion. Tschischwitz suggests 'keeps in his wonder, wraps himself in clouds.'

101.play: And wants not buzzers to infect his ear

102.play: With pestilent speeches of his father's death;
notes: Johnson: Wherein] Wherein (that is, in which pestilent speeches) necessity, or the obligation of an accuser to support his charge, will nothing stick, &c. [and he so prints it. Ed.] See Blackstone's note on I, ii, 109. Coleridge: Fearful and self-suspicious as I always feel when I seem to see an error of judgement in Sh., yet I can not reconcile the cool reflection in these lines with the anonymousness, or the alarm, of this Gentleman or Messenger.

104.play: Will nothing stick our person to arraign
notes: Dyce: person] The King is certainly speaking of himself only. Compare his reference to himself in other passages on the same subject, IV, i, 13, 15, 17. also IV, v, 118, 145.

105.play: In ear and ear. O my dear Gertrude, this,

106.play: Like to a murdering-piece, in many places
notes: Steevens: murdering-piece] 'A case shot is any kinde of small bullets, nailes, old iron, or the like, to put into the case, to shoot out of the ordinances or murderers; these will doe much mischiefe.' — Smith's Sea Grammar, 1627. Thus, in Beau. & Fl. The Double Marriage, IV, ii, 6: 'A father's curses . . . like a murdering-piece, aim not at one, But all that stand within the dangerous level.' Singer: A murdering-piece, or murderer, was a small piece of artillery; in Fr. meurtriere, which took its name from the loopholes and embrasures in towers and fortifications, that were so called. 'Meurtriere, c'est un petit canonniere comme celles des tours et murailles, ainsi appelle, parceque tirant par icelle a desceu, ceux ausquels on tire sont facilement meurtri.' — Nicot. 'Visiere meurtriere, a port-hole for a murthering Peece in the forecastle of a ship.' — Cotgrave. Dyce (Gloss.): 'Murdering-pieces,' if we may trust Coles, were not always 'small,' for he gives 'A murdering-piece, Tormentum murale; and afterwards 'Tormentum murale, a great gun.' — Lat. and Eng. Diet.

109.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : Alack, what noise is this?

110.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Where are my Switzers? Let them guard the door.
notes: Reed: Switzers] In many of our old plays the guards attendant on kings are called 'Switzers,' and that without any regard to the country where the scene lies. Malone: 'Law, logicke and the Switzers, may be hired to fight for any body.' — Nash, Christ's Teares over Jerusalem, 1594.

112.play: KING CLAUDIUS : What is the matter?

114.play: The ocean, overpeering of his list,
notes: Petri (Archivf. n. Sprachen, vol. vi, p. 93): overpeering] Petri suggests overpiering, i.e. over the piers, 'which is more picturesque, and in accordance with nature.'

115.play: Eats not the flats with more impetuous haste
notes: Malone: list] Boundary, i.e. shore. [For 'of his list,' see I, v, 175; Abbott, § 178.]

Dyce (ed. 2): Eats] W. W. Williams (under the signature W. D.), in The Literary Gazette for March 15, 1862, p. 263, would read Beats. But is not 'Eats' to be defended on classical authority? 'et ripas radentia flumina rodunt.' — Lucretius, v, 256. 'Non rura, quae Liris quieta Mordet aqua, taciturnus amnis.' — Horace, Carm. i, xxxi, 7.

116.play: Than young Laertes, in a riotous head,
notes: Clarendon: head] 'A head' is an armed force, as in 1 Hen. IV: I, iii, 284; lb. III, ii, 167.

117.play: O'erbears your officers. The rabble call him lord;
notes: Collier (ed. 2): lord] The (MS) would warrant us in changing 'lord' to king; perhaps the meaning of the rabble was the same, but afterwards they are represented as exclaiming 'Laertes shall be king.' Perhaps it ought to be king in both places.

118.play: And, as the world were now but to begin,

notes: Moberly: custom] As if the government were to be settled by random plebiscites at the good pleasure of the rabble.

120.play: The ratifiers and props of every word,
notes: Warburton: word] Certainly Sh. wrote ward, i.e. the security that nature and law place about the person of a king. Johnson: I think the fault can be mended at less expense by reading weal, i.e. of every government. Tyrwhitt: I should be rather for reading work. Capell, who adopted Tyrwhitt's conj., says (Notes, i, 143): Work is work of such sort as the people were about to proceed to. Heath (p. 544): By 'word' is here meant a declaration or proposal, referring to 'the rabble call him lord.' Tollet believed the sense to be 'the ratifiers and props of every word he utters.'* Caldecott: 'Word' is term, and means appellation or title; as 'lord' and 'king;' in its more extended sense it must import 'every human establishment.' Elze (Athenæum, 11 Aug. '66): Read worth. As far as worth is concerned, Laer. would indeed be a proper person to be elected king. But the king is not chosen for his worthiness; antiquity and custom claim a share also; they are 'the ratifiers and props of every worth.' Tschischwitz 'I hold wont to be the true reading [and he so prints it. Ed.] See Blackstone's note on I, ii, 109. Coleridge: Fearful and self-suspicious as I always feel when I seem to see an error of judgement in Sh., yet I can not reconcile the cool reflection in these lines with the anonymousness, or the alarm, of this Gentleman or Messenger.

121.play: They cry 'Choose we: Laertes shall be king:'

122.play: Caps, hands, and tongues, applaud it to the clouds:

124.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : How cheerfully on the false trail they cry!

125.play: O, this is counter, you false Danish dogs!
notes: Clarendon: counter] In Holmes's Academy of Armory, Bk II, c. ix, p. 187, 'counter' is defined: 'When a hound hunteth backwards, the same way that the chase is come.'

126.play: KING CLAUDIUS : The doors are broke.

129.play: LAERTES : Where is this king? Sirs, stand you all without.

131.play: LAERTES : I pray you, give me leave.

134.play: LAERTES : I thank you: keep the door. O thou vile king,

notes: Corson: calm] F1 reads better. Laer. is under the wildest excitement, with not a calm drop of blood in his veins, and when the Queen entreats, 'Calmly, good Laertes,' be or become calm, he replies, 'That drop of blood that calms,' that is, that grows calm, or will calm, 'proclaims me bastard;' 'calms' and 'proclaims' are both future in force.

137.play: LAERTES : That drop of blood that's calm proclaims me bastard,

138.play: Cries cuckold to my father, brands the harlot

139.play: Even here, between the chaste unsmirched brow
notes: Steevens: unsmirched] Clean, not defiled. This seems to be an allusion to a proverb often introduced in the old comedies. Thus, in The London Prodigal, 1605: 'as true as the skin between any man's brows.' Collier (ed. 2): This seems the only place where Sh. uses this word, meaning unsullied. We have elsewhere 'smirched' and 'besmirched' for dirtied.
White: brows] 'Between' shows that the s is manifestly needed.

141.play: KING CLAUDIUS : What is the cause, Laertes,

142.play: That thy rebellion looks so giant-like?
notes: Delius: true] That is, faithful.

143.play: Let him go, Gertrude; do not fear our person:

144.play: There's such divinity doth hedge a king,
notes: Delius: fear] See I, iii, 51.

Delius: person] It is to be inferred that the Queen throws herself between her husband and the enraged Laer. Clarendon: She clings round the latter to prevent him from striking. [See Dr Johnson's stage-direction, Textual Notes, line 112.] 145-147: Coleridge: There's . . . will] Proof, as indeed all else is, that Sh never intended us to see the King with Hamlet's eyes; though, I suspect, the managers have long done so.

Boswell: divinity] In Chettle's Englandes Mourning Garment is the following anecdote of Queen Elizabeth: While her Majesty was on the river near Greenwich, a shot was fired by accident, which struck the royal barge, and hurt a waterman near her. 'The French ambassador being amazed, and all crying Treason, Treason! yet she, with an undaunted spirit, came to the open place of the barge, and bad them never feare, for if the shot were made at her, they durst not shoots againe: such majestie had her presence, and such boldnesse her heart, that she despised all feare, and was, as all princes are or should be, so full of divine fullnesse, that guiltie mortalitie durst not beholde her but with dazeled eyes.'
Caldecott: hedge] See Job, i, 10; and iii, 23.

145.play: That treason can but peep to what it would,

146.play: Acts little of his will. Tell me, Laertes,
notes: Clarendon: world] The reading of the Qq is perhaps right. The extravagant hyperbole 'al' thf worH' which Laer. would thus use in reference to his former words, 'both the worlds,' is not unsuitable to his excited state of mind. [Pope's] reading might be the meaning of the reading of Qq, in which no apostrophe is used to distinguish the genitive singular from the nominative plural. White pronounces Pope's reading 'cramped, literal, inferior.'

147.play: Why thou art thus incensed. Let him go, Gertrude.

151.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : But not by him.

152.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Let him demand his fill.

153.play: LAERTES : How came he dead? I'll not be juggled with:

154.play: To hell, allegiance! vows, to the blackest devil!

155.play: Conscience and grace, to the profoundest pit!

156.play: I dare damnation. To this point I stand,

157.play: That both the worlds I give to negligence,

158.play: Let come what comes; only I'll be revenged

160.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Who shall stay you?

161.play: LAERTES : My will, not all the world:

162.play: And for my means, I'll husband them so well,

163.play: They shall go far with little.

165.play: If you desire to know the certainty

166.play: Of your dear father's death, is't writ in your revenge,

167.play: That, swoopstake, you will draw both friend and foe,
notes: Clarendon: swoopstake] The metaphor is from a game at cards, where the winner sweeps or 'draws' the whole stake. The meaning is somewhat confused by this admixture of metaphor. Moberly: Are you going to vent your rage on both friend and foe; like a gambler who insists on sweeping the stakes, whether the point is in his favor or not?

170.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Will you know them then?

171.play: LAERTES : To his good friends thus wide I'll ope my arms;

172.play: And like the kind life-rendering pelican,
notes: Caldecott: pelican] Caldecott quotes Dr Sherwen: 'By the pelican's dropping upon its breast its lower bill to enable its young to take from its capacious pouch, lined with a fine flesh-colored skin, this appearance is, on feeding them, given. H. B. Forrest [N. & Qu., 26 June, 1869) suggests that Sh. might have drawn his Knowledge on this point from Prodigorum ac Ostentorum Chronicon., Basileae, 1557. Moreover, in this book there is a full description of 'The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads Do grow beneath their shoulders.' Rushton (Shakespeare's Euphuism, p. 9) cites 'the Pelicane, who stricketh bloud out of hir owne bodye to do others good.' — Euphues and his England (p. 341, ed. Arber). Clarendon: In Rich. II: II, i, 126, and Lear, III, iv, 77, young pelicans are used as illustrations of filial impiety.

174.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Why, now you speak

175.play: Like a good child and a true gentleman.

176.play: That I am guiltless of your father's death,

177.play: And am most sensible in grief for it,

178.play: It shall as level to your judgment pierce

179.play: As day does to your eye.

181.play: LAERTES : How now! what noise is that?

183.play: LAERTES : O heat, dry up my brains! tears seven times salt,

184.play: Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!

185.play: By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight,

186.play: Till our scale turn the beam. O rose of May!

187.play: Dear maid, kind sister, sweet Ophelia!

188.play: O heavens! is't possible, a young maid's wits

189.play: Should be as moral as an old man's life?

190.play: Nature is fine in love, and where 'tis fine,

191.play: It sends some precious instance of itself

194.play: They bore him barefaced on the bier;

195.play: Hey non nonny, nonny, hey nonny;

196.play: And in his grave rain'd many a tear:--

198.play: LAERTES : Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade revenge,

203.play: O, how the wheel becomes it! It is the false

204.play: steward, that stole his master's daughter.

205.play: LAERTES : This nothing's more than matter.

206.play: OPHELIA : There's rosemary, that's for remembrance; pray,

207.play: love, remember: and there is pansies. that's for thoughts.

208.play: LAERTES : A document in madness, thoughts and remembrance fitted.

209.play: OPHELIA : There's fennel for you, and columbines: there's rue

210.play: for you; and here's some for me: we may call it

211.play: herb-grace o' Sundays: O you must wear your rue with

212.play: a difference. There's a daisy: I would give you

213.play: some violets, but they withered all when my father

214.play: died: they say he made a good end,--

216.play: For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy.

217.play: LAERTES : Thought and affliction, passion, hell itself,

218.play: She turns to favour and to prettiness.

220.play: And will he not come again?

221.play: And will he not come again?

225.play: His beard was as white as snow,

227.play: He is gone, he is gone,

229.play: God ha' mercy on his soul!

230.play: And of all Christian souls, I pray God. God be wi' ye.

232.play: LAERTES : Do you see this, O God?

233.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Laertes, I must commune with your grief,

234.play: Or you deny me right. Go but apart,

235.play: Make choice of whom your wisest friends you will.

236.play: And they shall hear and judge 'twixt you and me:

237.play: If by direct or by collateral hand

238.play: They find us touch'd, we will our kingdom give,

239.play: Our crown, our life, and all that we can ours,

240.play: To you in satisfaction; but if not,

241.play: Be you content to lend your patience to us,

242.play: And we shall jointly labour with your soul

245.play: His means of death, his obscure funeral--

246.play: No trophy, sword, nor hatchment o'er his bones,

247.play: No noble rite nor formal ostentation--

248.play: Cry to be heard, as 'twere from heaven to earth,

249.play: That I must call't in question.

251.play: And where the offence is let the great axe fall.

252.play: I pray you, go with me.

2.play: HORATIO : What are they that would speak with me?

3.play: Servant : Sailors, sir: they say they have letters for you.

6.play: HORATIO : I do not know from what part of the world

7.play: I should be greeted, if not from Lord Hamlet.

9.play: First Sailor : God bless you, sir.

10.play: HORATIO : Let him bless thee too.

11.play: First Sailor : He shall, sir, an't please him. There's a letter for

12.play: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was

13.play: bound for England; if your name be Horatio, as I am

notes: Clarendon: let to know] Caused to know, informed. Compare the phrase 'do to wit.'

15.play: HORATIO : [Reads] 'Horatio, when thou shalt have overlooked

16.play: this, give these fellows some means to the king:
notes: Caldecott: means] Means of access, introduction.

17.play: they have letters for him. Ere we were two days old

18.play: at sea, a pirate of very warlike appointment gave us
notes: Coleridge: pirate] This is almost the only play of Sh. in which mere accidents, independent of all will, form an essential part of the plot;—but here how judiciously in keeping with the character of the over-meditative Ham., ever at last determined by accident or by a fit of passion.

19.play: chase. Finding ourselves too slow of sail, we put on

20.play: a compelled valour, and in the grapple I boarded

21.play: them: on the instant they got clear of our ship; so
notes: Clarendon: as] We must either take 'as' = as though, or supply withal after 'death.'

22.play: I alone became their prisoner. They have dealt with

23.play: me like thieves of mercy: but they knew what they
notes: Clarendon: thieves of mercy] Merciful thieves. See note on I, ii, 4.

24.play: did; I am to do a good turn for them. Let the king
notes: Miles (p. 70): what they did] Miles maintains that this capture was not accidental, but was pre-arranged by Ham., who hints at it when he says to the King (IV, iii, 47), 'I see a cherub that sees them,' but alludes to it most positively and specifically at the close of the interview with his mother: 'O 'tis most sweet When in one line two crafts directly meet.'—'If the word crafts had its present maritime significance in Shakespeare's time, the pun alone is conclusive of a pre-arranged capture. How arranged is neither here nor there; but opportunities of chartering a free cruiser could not have been wanting to a prince of Denmark, and, what is more significant, the fleet of Fortinbras was then in port at Elsinor. There is an understanding, just ever so vaguely glanced at, between the two young princes. But the following lines admit of but one interpretation: "Let it work; For 'tis the sport to have the enginer Hoist with his own petar; and 't shall go hard But I will delve one YARD BELOW THEIR MINES AND BLOW THEM AT THE MOON !" One would think it required a miraculous allowance of critical obtuseness to ignore a counterplot so strikingly pre- announced. . . . To make assurance doubly sure, comes the letter to Hor., "In the grapple I boarded them; on the instant they got clear of our ship; so I alone became their prisoner. They dealt with me like thieves of mercy; BUT THEY KNEW WHAT THEY DID." Can circumstantial proof go farther? Could any twelve men of sense, on such a record, acquit Ham. of being an accessory before, as well as after the fact?' [See Snider, Appendix, Vol. II, p.

25.play: have the letters I have sent; and repair thou to me

26.play: with as much speed as thou wouldst fly death. I

27.play: have words to speak in thine ear will make thee
notes: Abbott: will make] For instances of the omission of the relative, see Abbott, § 244, and Macb. V, vii, 7.

28.play: dumb; yet are they much too light for the bore of
notes: Johnson: bore] The calibre of a gun, or the capacity of the barrel. 'The matter would carry heavier words.' Tschischwitz cannot persuade himself that 'bore' is not a verbal substantive from 'to bear,' and means 'capacity for bearing.'

29.play: the matter. These good fellows will bring thee

30.play: where I am. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern hold their

31.play: course for England: of them I have much to tell

notes: Clarke: He that thou knowest thine,] This simple yet strong conclusion to his sedate but most earnest letter to his bosom-friend might, we think, fully serve to denote Hamlet's perfect sanity. Madmen do not write in a style thus condensed and pertinent; if they are warm they are violent, if they are fervent they are excited; but here is warmth of friendship with staid expression, fervour of feeling with sobriety of assurance.

34.play: HORATIO : Come, I will make you way for these your letters;

35.play: And do't the speedier, that you may direct me

36.play: To him from whom you brought them.

2.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal,
notes: Rushton: acquittance seal] For other similar instances of Shakespeare's use of legal phraseology in reference to seals, see Rushton, Sh. a Lawyer, p. 29.

3.play: And you must put me in your heart for friend,
notes: See II, ii, 6; IV, iv, 45.

4.play: Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear,

5.play: That he which hath your noble father slain

7.play: LAERTES : It well appears: but tell me

8.play: Why you proceeded not against these feats,
notes: Clarendon: The Qq make this line an Alexandrine. But this is no grave objection, as the next line is Alexandrine also. Walker (Crit. iii, 269) proposed to make 'As by' a line by itself, but withdrew it, as 'much too harsh.'

9.play: So crimeful and so capital in nature,
notes: Clarendon: crimeful] The Ff are probably right in giving this rarer word, which is not used elsewhere by Sh.

10.play: As by your safety, wisdom, all things else,

12.play: KING CLAUDIUS : O, for two special reasons;

13.play: Which may to you, perhaps, seem much unsinew'd,
notes: 'Glauca canentia fronde salicta.' Lowell (Among My Books, p. 185): Sh. understood perfectly the charm of indirectness, of making his readers seem to discover for themselves what he means to show them. If he wishes to tell that the leaves of the willow are gray on the under side, he does not make it a mere fact of observation by bluntly saying so, but makes it picturesquely reveal itself to us as it might in Nature.

14.play: But yet to me they are strong. The queen his mother

15.play: Lives almost by his looks; and for myself--

16.play: My virtue or my plague, be it either which--
notes: Abbott: be it either which] There is, perhaps, a confusion between 'be it either,' and 'be it whichever of the two.' Perhaps, however, 'either' may be taken in its original sense of 'one of the two,' so that 'either which' is 'which-one-so-ever of the two.'

17.play: She's so conjunctive to my life and soul,

18.play: That, as the star moves not but in his sphere,

19.play: I could not but by her. The other motive,

20.play: Why to a public count I might not go,
notes: Abbott: count] For account.

21.play: Is the great love the general gender bear him;
notes: Johnson: general gender] The common race of the people. Delius: 'Gender' is applied to herbs in Oth. I, iii, 326. CALDECOTT: See 'the general,' II, ii, 416.

22.play: Who, dipping all his faults in their affection,

23.play: Would, like the spring that turneth wood to stone,
notes: Clarendon: Would] The Qq make 'convert' indicative instead of infinitive. But 'Would convert' seems required by the context.

Johnson: spring] This simile is neither very seasonable in the deep interest of this conversation, nor very accurately applied. If the spring had changed base metals to gold, the thought had been more proper. Reed: The allusion is to the qualities of the dropping-well at Knaresborough, in Yorkshire. Camden (1590, p. 564) thus mentions it: 'Sub quo fons est in quem ex impendentibus rupibus aquae guttatim distillant, unde Dropping Well vocant, in quem quicquid ligni immittitur, lapideo cortice brevi obduci et lapidescere observatum est.' Clarendon: Lily has: 'Would I had sipped of that ryuer in Caria, which turneth those that drinke of it to stones.' — Euphues, p. 63, ed. Arber.

24.play: Convert his gyves to graces; so that my arrows,
notes: Theobald (Nichols's Lit. Hist, ii, 576): gyves] I own I do not understand this. I have conjectured gybes, i.e. even gybes, mocks, fleering, &c, would in him be construed graces. [This was not repeated in Theobald's ed., but it is adopted by Tschischwitz. Ed.] Elze: Perhaps we should read crimes. Clarke: That is, turn all my attempts to restrain him into so many injuries perpetrated against his innocence and good qualities. Daniel (p. 76): Read gyres, i.e. his 'wild and whirling' actions, his mad eccentricities. Clarendon: Compare, 'And made their bends adornings.' — Ant. & Cleo. II. ii, 213. Elze (Shakespeare-Jahrbuch, xi, 295, and also The Athenaeum, 20 Feb. 1869): The corruption appears to be here not in 'gyves,' but in 'graces.' How can corporeal 'gyves' be converted into incorporeal, abstract 'graces'? That is more than even the well at Knaresborough could do. An abstract noun in this connection ruins the whole metaphor, and is illogical. If we substitute some abstract noun for 'gyves,' while restoring logical propriety, we deprive the simile of all significant clearness, force, and depth, and to introduce the wonder-working spring in order to compare together two abstract qualities would be pointless, and assuredly not in accordance with Shakespeare's genius and style. Read, therefore: graves. Graves, now spelled greaves, is found also in 2 Hen. IV: IV, iv, 50, where, as here, something mean becomes ennobled. For the spelling, compare 'thraves,' instead of threaves (Chapman's Iliad, xi, 477); and 'stale,' instead of steale or stele (lb. iv, 173). Stratmann praises this emendation of Elze's as judicious.

25.play: Too slightly timber'd for so loud a wind,
notes: Caldecott: timber'd] Sh. uses this in reference to a suit of armor being too slightly timbered for so loud a wind, which is not only possible, but just. (See Ascham's Toxophilus, p. 151, ed. Arber: 'Weake bowes, and lyghte shaftes can not stande in a rough wynde.') 29-30: Abbott: have ... driven] Here note that though the first line could be re-transposed, and Laer. could naturally say, 'I have lost a father,' on the other hand he could not say, 'I have driven a sister,' without completely changing the sense. 'Have' is here used in its original sense, and is equivalent to 'I find.' When 'have' is thus used without any notion of action, it is separated from the participle passive. See I, ii, 215; III, iii, 38.

26.play: Would have reverted to my bow again,

27.play: And not where I had aim'd them.

28.play: LAERTES : And so have I a noble father lost;

29.play: A sister driven into desperate terms,

30.play: Whose worth, if praises may go back again,

31.play: Stood challenger on mount of all the age
notes: Johnson: praises] If I may praise what has been, but is now to be found no more.

32.play: For her perfections: but my revenge will come.
notes: Caldecott: on mount] On the highest ground, in the fullest presence of the age, to give a general challenge in support of her excellence. [Ed. note: but see next comment, that 'of all the age' qualifies 'challenger,' i.e., her worth challenged all the age to deny her perfection. Collier (ed. 2): The (MS) reads sole challenger. Moberly: The allusion seems to be the coronation ceremony of the Emperor of Germany as King of Hungary; when on the Mount of Defiance, at Presburg, he unsheathes the ancient sword of state, and shaking it towards North, South, East, and West, challenges the four corners of the world to dispute his rights.]

33.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Break not your sleeps for that: you must not think

34.play: That we are made of stuff so flat and dull
notes: See I, i, 173. Dyce quotes from Phaer's Virgil, ALneidos, ii: 'The towne .... in sleepes [the original somno] and drinking drownd;' and refers to 2 Hen. IV: IV, v, 69, where he also reads 'sleeps.'

35.play: That we can let our beard be shook with danger

36.play: And think it pastime. You shortly shall hear more:
notes: For instances of 'with' equivalent to by, see Macb. III, i, 62; IV, ii, 32; and Abbott, § 193.

37.play: I loved your father, and we love ourself;
notes: Seymour (ii, 196): I ... ourself] Seymour, losing sight of the distinction here implied between the feelings of a man and those of a king, says that in the beginning of this speech the King seems to have forgotten the pompous dignity of his plural distinction.

38.play: And that, I hope, will teach you to imagine--

40.play: KING CLAUDIUS : How now! what news?

41.play: Messenger : Letters, my lord, from Hamlet:
notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 208): Of him] 'Him' for them, I suspect. [Would 'he received them of them that brought them' be tolerable? Ed.] Tschischwitz thinks he has mended matters by giving this speech to a servant instead of to a messenger.

42.play: This to your majesty; this to the queen.

43.play: KING CLAUDIUS : From Hamlet! who brought them?

44.play: Messenger : Sailors, my lord, they say; I saw them not:

45.play: They were given me by Claudio; he received them
notes: Clarendon: eyes] See IV, iv, 6.

47.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Laertes, you shall hear them. Leave us.

50.play: 'High and mighty, You shall know I am set naked on
notes: See Macb. IV, iii, 49, or Abbott, § 325.

51.play: your kingdom. To-morrow shall I beg leave to see

52.play: your kingly eyes: when I shall, first asking your

53.play: pardon thereunto, recount the occasion of my sudden

notes: Abbott: more strange] 'My sudden, and even more strange than sudden.'

55.play: KING CLAUDIUS : What should this mean? Are all the rest come back?

56.play: Or is it some abuse, and no such thing?

notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 269): character] The verse seems to require that this word (character, as it is, frequently at least, accented in the old poets) should be pronounced ch'ract', as it is in Middleton's The Roaring Girl, Prologue, 'WTith wings more lofty; thus her character lies.' [—p. 435, ed. Dyce.]

59.play: And in a postscript here, he says 'alone.'

61.play: LAERTES : I'm lost in it, my lord. But let him come;

62.play: It warms the very sickness in my heart,

63.play: That I shall live and tell him to his teeth,

notes: Staunton: Thus ... thou] The reading of Qq may be thought superior by some.

65.play: KING CLAUDIUS : If it be so, Laertes--

66.play: As how should it be so? how otherwise?--
notes: Delius: As ... otherwise] We should expect 'How should it not be so?' Sh. is elsewhere inexact in repeating and in omitting the negative. Keightley (Expositor, p. 295): It is manifest that but or not has been omitted. [Keightley reads 'should it but' in his text.] Clarendon: Perhaps the first clause refers to Hamlet's return, the second to Laertes's feelings. Marshall (p. 197): If the 'should' were italicised we might make sense of it, thus: 'If it be so'— (i.e. if Ham. has come back because, on consideration, he did not choose to go to England)—'As how should it be so?' (i.e. how should there be any question about it being so?)—'How (could it be) otherwise?' I admit that in this case we should expect 'if' to be repeated.

67.play: Will you be ruled by me?
notes: White: Will ... me?] The most un-Shakespearian want of accord between the rhythm and the sense of this hemistich,—the accent being thrown upon 'by' instead of 'me,'—warrants the opinion that the intelligent correction in the Folio is by authority. [It is to be borne in mind that White supposes 'ruled' is to be pronounced as a dissyllable. In his text he prints 'rul'd,' and, following the Ff, omits 'Ay, my lord.' Ed.]
Walker (Crit. iii, 270): my lord] Perhaps 'my good lord.'

69.play: So you will not o'errule me to a peace.

70.play: KING CLAUDIUS : To thine own peace. If he be now return'd,

71.play: As checking at his voyage, and that he means
notes: Abbott: As] 'As' is used nearly redundantly before participles to denote a cause, 'inasmuch as.'

Steevens: checking] The phrase is from falconry. 'For who knows not, quoth she, that this hawk, which comes now so fair to the fist, may to-morrow check at my lure?'—Hinde's Eliosto Libidinoso, 1606. Dyce (Gloss.): Applied to a hawk when she forsakes her proper game and follows some other of inferior kind that crosses her in her flight. Clarendon: Compare Twelfth Night, II, v. 124, and III, i, 71. The use of the word is not quite the same here, because the voyage was Hamlet's 'proper game,' which he abandons. Collier (ed. 1): 'Checking at' was doubtless introduced in the Ff as a conjectural emendation. [Not repeated in Collier's ed. 2.] Dyce: The Ff reading is much more in Shakespeare's manner than liking not.

72.play: No more to undertake it, I will work him

73.play: To an exploit, now ripe in my device,

74.play: Under the which he shall not choose but fall:

75.play: And for his death no wind of blame shall breathe,

76.play: But even his mother shall uncharge the practise
notes: Caldecott: uncharge] Acquit of blame. Clarendon: The word is probably coined by Sh. for the nonce.
Clarendon: practice] Plot, stratagem, treachery. See IV, vii, 139; V, ii, 304.

78.play: LAERTES : My lord, I will be ruled;

79.play: The rather, if you could devise it so

80.play: That I might be the organ.

82.play: You have been talk'd of since your travel much,

83.play: And that in Hamlet's hearing, for a quality

84.play: Wherein, they say, you shine: your sum of parts

85.play: Did not together pluck such envy from him

86.play: As did that one, and that, in my regard,

notes: Johnson: siege] Of the lowest rank. Clarendon: Seat, thence rank, because people sat at table and elsewhere in order of precedence.

88.play: LAERTES : What part is that, my lord?

89.play: KING CLAUDIUS : A very riband in the cap of youth,

90.play: Yet needful too; for youth no less becomes

91.play: The light and careless livery that it wears

92.play: Than settled age his sables and his weeds,

93.play: Importing health and graveness. Two months since,
notes: Warburton: health] But a warm furred gown rather implies sickness than “health.” Sh. wrote wealth, i. e. that the wearers are rich burghers and magistrates. [Moberly: This emendation gives better sense.] Johnson: 'Importing' here may be not inferring by logical consequence, but producing by physical effect. A young man regards show in his dress, an old man, health. MALONE: 'Importing health' means denoting an attention to health. Steevens: 'Importing' may only signify,—implying, denoting. Malone's explanation may be the true one. Clarendon adopts Malone's explanation. [See Rom. & Jul. I, i, 86. May not this be an instance of what Corson (Cornell Rev. Nov. 1876) calls respective construction, and 'health' refer to 'careless livery,' and 'graveness' to 'sables' and 'weeds'? Compare III, i, 151.] 94-95: Caldecott: Normandy . . . against] With the punctuation of the QqFf the construction may be: "Here was a gentleman [whom] I've seen myself, and [I have also] served against the French, And they," &c.

94.play: Here was a gentleman of Normandy:--

95.play: I've seen myself, and served against, the French,

96.play: And they can well on horseback: but this gallant
notes: Collier: can] The ran of Ff is a mere misprint; people do not run on horseback. See Abbott, § 307, for other instances, found, though very rarely, in Sh. of this, the original meaning of 'can.' Clarendon: Compare Bacon, Essay xi, p. 40: 'In evil the best condition is not to will, the second not to can.'

97.play: Had witchcraft in't; he grew unto his seat;

98.play: And to such wondrous doing brought his horse,

99.play: As he had been incorpsed and demi-natured

100.play: With the brave beast: so far he topp'd my thought,
notes: Dyce (Gloss.): topp'd] To rise above, to surpass. See Macb. IV, iii, 57; Lear, I, ii, 21.

101.play: That I, in forgery of shapes and tricks,
notes: Johnson: forgery] I could not contrive so many proofs of dexterity as he could perform.

102.play: Come short of what he did.

notes: Malone: Lamond] Sh. wrote, I suspect, Lamode. See lines 94, 95, where he is spoken of as 'the brooch and gem of all the nation.' Clarendon: The name appears to have been altogether fictitious. C Elliot Browne (Athenaeum, 29 July, 1876): It is not impossible that this is an allusion to Pietro Monte (in a Gallicized form), the famous cavalier and swordsman, who is mentioned by Castiglione ('Il Cortegiano' b. i) as the instructor of Louis the Seventh's Master of Horse. In the English translation he is called 'Peter Mount.' [I regret that these valuable Notes on Shakespeare's Names reached me too late to be inserted in due place in the commentary under the first appearance of each character. They will be found, however, in the Appendix, Vol. II, p. 241. Ed.]

107.play: LAERTES : I know him well: he is the brooch indeed
notes: Nares: brooch] An ornamental buckle, pin, or loop. From the French broche, a spit. It is frequently mentioned as an ornament worn in the hat.

108.play: And gem of all the nation.

109.play: KING CLAUDIUS : He made confession of you,
notes: Delius: confession] Here used, because Lamond would not willingly acknowledge the superiority of Laer. over the French in the art of fighting.

110.play: And gave you such a masterly report
notes: Clarendon: masterly report] A report which describes Laer. as a master of fence.

111.play: For art and exercise in your defence
notes: Johnson: defence] That is, in the science of defence.

112.play: And for your rapier most especially,

113.play: That he cried out, 'twould be a sight indeed,

114.play: If one could match you: the scrimers of their nation,
notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 270): Here, and in III, iii, 57, and IV, v, 119, Claudius, like the Ghost, shows something of Hamlet's philosophising turn.

115.play: He swore, had had neither motion, guard, nor eye,
notes: Johnson: begun by time] The meaning may be, love is not innate in us, and co-essential to our nature, but begins at a certain time from some external cause, and being always subject to the operations of time, suffers change and diminution. M. Mason: The King reasons thus:—'I do not suspect that you did not love your father; but I know that time abates the force of affection.' I therefore suspect that we ought to read: 'love is begone by time.' I suppose that Sh. places the syllable be before gone, as we say be-paint, be-spatter, be-think, &c, or possibly we should read 'by-gone.' Bailey (ii, 14): The dominant idea of the speech is that love is abated by time. Read 'love is begnawn by time,' an expression which exactly conveys the sense required, while the change requisite for perverting it into the received text is slight. Compare Rich. Ill : I, iii, 222 ; Tro. & Cres. IV, v, 293.

Seymour: by time] Read betime. The King means, 'love begins at an early period of life, but as our affections ripen this affection suffers abatement.' Keightley: I cannot make any good sense out of this. I suspect that 'time' may be owing to the same word lower down. The love spoken of seems to be that of children for parents, and possibly the word was childhood, birth.

116.play: If you opposed them. Sir, this report of his
notes: Johnson: proof] In transactions of daily experience. Clarendon: Circumstances which prove that time abates love. Compare II, i, 38.

117.play: Did Hamlet so envenom with his envy

118.play: That he could nothing do but wish and beg
notes: For other instances of the lengthened pronunciation of this word, see Walker, Vers. 144; Abbott, § 480.

119.play: Your sudden coming o'er, to play with him.

121.play: LAERTES : What out of this, my lord?

122.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Laertes, was your father dear to you?

123.play: Or are you like the painting of a sorrow,

126.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Not that I think you did not love your father;

127.play: But that I know love is begun by time;

128.play: And that I see, in passages of proof,

129.play: Time qualifies the spark and fire of it.

130.play: There lives within the very flame of love

131.play: A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it;

132.play: And nothing is at a like goodness still;

133.play: For goodness, growing to a plurisy,

134.play: Dies in his own too much: that we would do
notes: Warburton: plurisy] I would believe, for the honor of Sh., that he wrote plethory. But I observe the dramatic writers of that time frequently call a fullness of blood a pleurisy, as if it came not from πλευρά, but from plus, pluris. [In sum, the commentators agree “plurisy” is used as if for “plethora,” the actual medical pleurisy being misunderstood as an excess or redundancy, a surfeit, not in the modern sense.] 137-140: Tschischwitz: that ... accidents] The fundamental idea of the whole tragedy. Grant White (Hamlet the Younger, Galaxy, April, 1870, p. 544) says the same.

Moberly: too-much] Like 'a great amiss,' 'the why and wherefore,' and the like. English had at this time something like the flexibility of the Greek, and had no difficulty in throwing out phrases like τὸ ἄγαν and τὸ πρίν.

135.play: We should do when we would; for this 'would' changes
notes: See I, v, 32; III, iii, 75; Macb. I, v, 19, and III, vi, 19.

136.play: And hath abatements and delays as many

137.play: As there are tongues, are hands, are accidents;

138.play: And then this 'should' is like a spendthrift sigh,
notes: Warburton: spendthrift sigh] This nonsense should be read 'a spendthrift's sign,' i.e. though a spendthrift's entering into bonds or mortgages gives him a present relief from his straits, yet it ends in much greater distresses. Heath: This refers to a very idle opinion, still prevalent among the common people, that every sigh draws drops of blood from the heart and tends to shorten life. Caldecott cites Dr Sherwen: To have conceived, previous to the discovery of the circulation of the blood, that sighing sucked the blood, was an idea natural enough for after, or rather during, a deep sigh the blood flows more freely through the pulmonary artery and its ramifications in the different lobes of the lungs; and it might have appeared to the old physiologists to be thus drawn away from the heart and the general mass into the lungs. How it got back again into the heart, they did not know. Clarendon: The meaning is that the mere recognition of a duty without the will to perform it, while it satisfies for a moment, enfeebles the moral nature. We have the same notion of sighs wasting the vital powers in 2 Hen. VI: III, ii, 63; Mid. N. D., Ill, ii, 97. [See Rom. & Jul. Ill, v, 58.] Moberly: He who vainly acknowledges that he 'should' have done a thing is like a spendthrift sighing for his squandered estate.
Clarendon: sanctuarize] This verb is probably invented by Sh. No place should protect murder (such as that which Ham. has perpetrated) from punishment. Compare Rich. Ill III, i, 42; Cor. I, x, 19.

139.play: That hurts by easing. But, to the quick o' the ulcer:--

140.play: Hamlet comes back: what would you undertake,

141.play: To show yourself your father's son in deed

143.play: LAERTES : To cut his throat i' the church.

144.play: KING CLAUDIUS : No place, indeed, should murder sanctuarize;

145.play: Revenge should have no bounds. But, good Laertes,

146.play: Will you do this, keep close within your chamber.
notes: See II, i, 90.

147.play: Hamlet return'd shall know you are come home:

148.play: We'll put on those shall praise your excellence

149.play: And set a double varnish on the fame

150.play: The Frenchman gave you, bring you in fine together

151.play: And wager on your heads: he, being remiss,

152.play: Most generous and free from all contriving,

153.play: Will not peruse the foils; so that, with ease,

154.play: Or with a little shuffling, you may choose

155.play: A sword unbated, and in a pass of practise
notes: Pope (ed. 2): unbated] Not blunted, as foils are. Or, as one edition has it, embaited or envenomed. [No edition has yet been found with this reading. Theobald first conjectured imbaited.] Steevens: In North's Plutarch it is said of one of the Metelli, that 'he shewed the people the cruel fight of fencers at unrebated swords.' Malone: Not blunted, as foils are by a button fixed to the end. So in Love's Lab. I, i, 6: 'That honour, which shall bate his scythe's keen edge.' Clarendon: See Rich. Ill : V, v, 35. Also, 'rebate,' Meas. for Meas. I, iv, 60.

Johnson: practice] Although the meaning of stratagem, or privy treason, is not incongruous here, yet I rather believe that nothing more is meant than a thrust for exercise. M. Mason: It means a favorite pass, one that Laer. was well practiced in. The treachery lay in the use of a sword unbated and envenomed. Clarendon: A treacherous thrust. See line 76 of this scene.
Moberly: anoint] Laer. shows by this horrid suggestion how little need there was for the King to prepare the temptation as carefully as he did.

158.play: And, for that purpose, I'll anoint my sword.

159.play: I bought an unction of a mountebank,
notes: Clarendon: mountebank] Quack-doctor. See Oth. I, iii, 61; and in Bacon's Advancement of Learning, ii, 10, § 2: 'Nay, we see the weakness and credulity of men is such, as they will often prefer a mountebank or witch before a learned physician.' In Jonson's Fox, Volpone, disguised as a mountebank, has a multitude of medicines to sell. In Italian he is called ciarlatano, whence the French charlatan, for which among others Cotgrave gives as equivalents, 'A Mountebanke, a cousening drug-seller, a pratling quack-saluer.'

160.play: So mortal that, but dip a knife in it,

161.play: Where it draws blood no cataplasm so rare,

162.play: Collected from all simples that have virtue

163.play: Under the moon, can save the thing from death
notes: Clarendon: simples] Herbs, so-called as being the simple ingredients of compound mixtures. See Rom. & Jul. V, i, 40.

164.play: That is but scratch'd withal: I'll touch my point
notes: To gather simples by moonlight was supposed to add to their medicinal power or 'virtue.'

165.play: With this contagion, that, if I gall him slightly,
notes: Clarendon: contagion] Used like 'unction,' line 159, for a material object, abstract for concrete, the thing which gives contagion.
For 'so that,' see IV, v, 211.

167.play: KING CLAUDIUS : Let's further think of this;

168.play: Weigh what convenience both of time and means

169.play: May fit us to our shape: if this should fail,
notes: Johnson: shape] May enable us to assume proper characters, and to act our part.

170.play: And that our drift look through our bad performance,

171.play: 'Twere better not assay'd: therefore this project

172.play: Should have a back or second, that might hold,

173.play: If this should blast in proof. Soft! let me see:
notes: Steevens: proof] A metaphor taken from the trying or proving of fire-arms or cannon, which blast or burst in the proof.

174.play: We'll make a solemn wager on your cunnings: I ha't.
notes: Caldecott: cunnings] commings of F, as a meeting in assault, bout, or pass at fence. Minsheu: 'Comming, Gall. Venue.' Cotgrave: 'Venue, f. A comming; also, a vennie in fencing.'

175.play: When in your motion you are hot and dry--

176.play: As make your bouts more violent to that end--

177.play: And that he calls for drink, I'll have prepared him
notes: Equivalent to 'For so.' See IV, iii, 58.

178.play: A chalice for the nonce, whereon but sipping,
notes: Clarendon: that] 'That' follows 'when,' after a parenthesis or other intervening words (compare Lear, II, i, 45), completing the conjunction 'When that,' which is used by Sh., as e.g. Jul. Cas. III, ii, 96: 'When that the poor have cried.'
White: prepared] The Qq are decidedly wrong. 'A goblet might be well spoken of as prepared for the nonce, but not as preferred [offered] for the nonce.'

179.play: If he by chance escape your venom'd stuck,
notes: Clarendon: nonce] For the special occasion. The phrase was originally 'for the once,' the 'n' being added for euphony. [See Matzner, vol. i, p. 181.] Hunter (ii, 260): There is little in our poet's writings more painful than such a scene as this; the cool deliberation with which Laer. comes into such a plot is so inconsistent with his character as exhibited in the other parts of the play; the clumsiness of the whole contrivance, and the barefaced manner in which the King is made to expose his villainous purpose to one who is already half his enemy, that one is tempted to ask where the mighty spirit is fled which dictated some portions of this most unequal performance. What an abandonment also of the great design of the tragedy (as announced in the First Act), that there should be a train laid which is to bring about the catastrophe while the principal actor is not cognizant of it, and has, of course, no part in it. The death of the King is in consequence brought about without that intention of the mind of Ham. which was necessary to connect it with the early scenes of the play, and to give dignity to the great catastrophe.

Blackstone: stuck] Read tuck, a common name for a rapier. Malone: 'Stuck,' a term of the fencing-school, means thrust. Dyce (Gloss.): More properly stuck, an abbreviation of stoccado. White speaks of an 'old copy' which reads, 'your venom'd trick.' [I have been unable to find any old copy which so reads. Ed.]

182.play: KING CLAUDIUS : How now, sweet queen!

183.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : One woe doth tread upon another's heel,
notes: Jennens: noise] Jennens finds great significance in these words, as an expression of the King's guilt, and fear of being overheard.

184.play: So fast they follow; your sister's drown'd, Laertes.

notes: Steevens: Compare Per. I, iv, 63. Ritson calls attention to a similar thought in Locrine, one of the Spurious Plays, first published in 1595. Sabren drowns herself, and Queen Gwendoline exclaims: 'One mischief follows another's neck.' [So it reads in the last column of the last page of F.]

186.play: QUEEN GERTRUDE : There is a willow grows aslant a broook,

187.play: That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream;

188.play: There with fantastic garlands did she come
notes: Thomas Campbell [?] (Blackwood's Maga. March, 1833): The Queen was affected after a fashion by the picturesque mode of Ophelia's death, and takes more pleasure in describing it than any one would who really had a heart. Gertrude was a gossip, — and she is gross even in her grief.
Hunter (ii, 261): willow] She resorted to the willow 'to make her a garland, as being forsaken,' as Benedick says of the Count.

Collier: aslant] Ascaunt has nearly the same meaning as 'aslant.' Beisley (p. 159): This willow, the Salix alba, grows on the banks of most of our small streams, particularly the Avon, near Stratford, and from the looseness of the soil the trees partly lose their hold, and bend 'aslant' over the stream.

189.play: Of crow-flowers, nettles, daisies, and long purples
notes: Clarke: hoar] Willow leaves are green on the upper side, but silvery-grey, or hoary, on the under side, which it shows in the glassy stream. Clarendon: Compare Virgil, Georgics, ii,

190.play: That liberal shepherds give a grosser name,
notes: Jennens: come] Interprets the Qq: With the willow she made a garland, and stuck flowers in it. Knight says: To 'make,' of the Qq, here means to 'come,' to 'make way,' to 'proceed.'

191.play: But our cold maids do dead men's fingers call them:
notes: Farren (Mania and Madness, &c, p. 62): This line is an exquisite specimen of emblematic or picture-writing. The 'crow-flower,' according to Parkinson, was called The fayre Mayde of France; the 'long purples' are dead men's fingers; the 'daisy' imports pure virginity or spring of life, as being itself 'the virgin bloom of the year.' The order runs thus, with the meaning of each flower beneath: Crow-flowers, Nettles,   Daisies,    Long Purples. virgin cold hand| bloom of death. / A fair maid stung to the quick, her virgin bloom under the cold hand of death. Beisley (p. 159): 'Crow-flowers' are the bulbous crowfoot, Ranunculus bulbosus, and the meadow crowfoot, R. acris. The most common 'nettles' which blossom early are the white dead-nettle, Lamium album, and the purple dead-nettle, L. purpureum. 'Daisy,' Bellis perennis; the only British species, blossoms all the year, and is one of the earliest flowers of spring.

Steevens: long purples] In Lyte's Herbal, 1578, its various names, too gross for repetition, are preserved. Malone: One of the grosser names Gertrude had a particular reason to avoid,—the rampant widow. Beisley (p. 160): This is the early purple orchis, Orchis mascula, which blossoms in April and May. The 'cold maids' mistook one of the other orchids, having palmated roots, for 'long purples.' The spotted palmate orchis, Orchis maculata, and the marsh orchis, O. latifolia, have palmated roots, and are called 'dead men's fingers,' which they somewhat resemble. [See also The Garden, 19 Sept. 1874.]

192.play: There, on the pendent boughs her coronet weeds
notes: Reed: liberal] Licentious. See Much Ado, IV, i, 93. Malone: Free-spoken. Clarendon: As in Rich. II: II, i, 229.

193.play: Clambering to hang, an envious sliver broke;
notes: Delius: cold] In opposition to 'liberal.'

194.play: When down her weedy trophies and herself

195.play: Fell in the weeping brook. Her clothes spread wide;
notes: See Macb. IV, i, 28.

196.play: And, mermaid-like, awhile they bore her up:

197.play: Which time she chanted snatches of old tunes;
notes: Jennens: tunes] The reading, 'tunes,' of the Ff is vague, while lauds of the Qq, i.e. hymns or psalms, tells us just what kind of music she died singing. Singer: Lauds were so called from the psalm Laudate Dominum. White: Lauds of the Qq is a word singularly inappropriate here. Hudson: Lauds might well be preferred, as agreeing better with chanted, and as conveying a touch of pathos which 'tunes' does not quite reach.

198.play: As one incapable of her own distress,
notes: Malone: incapable] Having no understanding or knowledge. See 'capable,' III, ii, 11; III, iv, 127. RITSON: That is, insensible. Caldecott: Thus: 'conducted into the great hall of the gods, Mercury sprinkled me with water, which made me capable of their divine presence.'— Greene's Orpharion, 1599.

199.play: Or like a creature native and indued
notes: For instances of the omission of the preposition in adverbial expressions of time, manner, &c, see Abbott, § 202.
See I, ii, 47.

MASON: indued] We should read either inured or indured. Sh. seems to have forgotten himself in this scene, as there is not a single circumstance in this relation which implies that Oph. had drowned herself intentionally. Malone: 'Indued' is clothed, endowed, or furnished with properties suited to the element of water. Our old writers used indued and endowed indiscriminately.

200.play: Unto that element: but long it could not be

201.play: Till that her garments, heavy with their drink,

202.play: Pull'd the poor wretch from her melodious lay

notes: Caldecott: muddy] Sh. uses 'mudded' twice in reference to drowning; see Temp. III, iii, 102; lb. V, i, 151.

Malone: death] In the first scene of the next Act we find Oph. buried with such rites as betoken she foredid her own life. It should be remembered that the account here given is that of a friend, and that the Queen could not possibly know what passed in the mind of Oph. when she placed herself in so perilous a situation. After the facts had been weighed and considered, the priest in the next Act pronounces that her death was doubtful. Seymour (ii, 197): As the Queen seems to give this description from ocular knowledge, it may be asked why, apprised as she was of Ophelia's distraction, she did not take steps to prevent the fatal catastrophe, especially as there was so fair an opportunity of saving her while she was, by her clothes, borne 'mermaid-like-up,' and the Queen was at leisure to hear her 'chanting old tunes.' T. C. [Thomas Campbell?] (Blackwood's Maga., Feb. 1818, p. 511): Perhaps this description by the Queen is poetical rather than dramatic; but its exquisite beauty prevails, and Oph., dying and dead, is still the same Oph. that first won our love. Perhaps the very forgetfulness of her throughout the remainder of the play, leaves the soul at full liberty to dream of the departed. She has passed away from the earth like a beautiful air,—a delightful dream. There would have been no place for her in the agitation and tempest of the final catastrophe. We are satisfied that she is in her grave. And in place of beholding her involved in the shocking troubles of the closing scene, we remember that her heart lies at rest, and the remembrance is like the returning voice of melancholy music. Hudson: This passage is deservedly celebrated, and aptly illustrates the Poet's power of making the description of a thing better than the thing itself, by giving us his eyes to see it with. CLARENDON: This speech of the Queen is certainly unworthy of its author and of the occasion. The enumeration of plants is quite as unsuitable to so tragical a scene as the description of the Dover cliff, in Lear, IV, vi, 11-24. Besides, there was no one by to witness the death of Oph., else she would have been rescued.

204.play: LAERTES : Alas, then, she is drown'd?
notes: Clarendon: poor wretch] So Ham. is called, II, ii, 167.

Corson: drown'd?] It would appear from the Queen's reply that Laertes's speech must have been meant to be interrogative. If exclamatory, the iteration thereupon of the Queen, 'Drown'd, drown'd,' is almost ludicrous, and makes one feel that the poor girl has had indeed, as Laer. says in the next speech, 'too much of water.'

Warburton: drown'd] Beau. & Fl. ridicule this passage: 'I will run mad first, and if that get not pity, I'll drown myself to a most dismal ditty.'—The Scornfull Lady, III, ii, p. 68, ed. Dyce. Elze finds another allusion to this passage in the same play of The Scornfull Lady, II, iii, p. 41: 'Drown'd, drown'd at sea.' [But this allusion is doubtful; the plot hinges on the supposed drowning at sea of the hero, and such a phrase could hardly be avoided. There are, however, undoubtedly other allusions to Hamlet elsewhere in the play. Ed.]

206.play: LAERTES : Too much of water hast thou, poor Ophelia,

207.play: And therefore I forbid my tears: but yet

208.play: It is our trick; nature her custom holds,
notes: Caldecott: trick] Our habit, a property that makes a part of us. Clarendon: See All's Well, III, ii, 9; Love's Lab. V, ii, 416. [Lear, IV, vi, 105.]

209.play: Let shame say what it will: when these are gone,

210.play: The woman will be out. Adieu, my lord:
notes: Steevens: woman] See Hen. V: IV, vi, 31. Caldecott: When these tears are shed this womanish passion will be over.

211.play: I have a speech of fire, that fain would blaze,

212.play: But that this folly douts it.

215.play: How much I had to do to calm his rage!

216.play: Now fear I this will give it start again;

1.play: Enter two Clowns, with spades, & c
notes: Scene I: Strachey (p. 88): The Clowns open this scene, partly to carry on the action partly to form, by their utter indifference to the tragedy that is enacting, a background which shall throw that tragedy and its actors into strong relief; and in particular to bring out Hamlet's character by contrasting it with such extreme opposites.

2.play: First Clown : Is she to be buried in Christian burial that

4.play: Second Clown : I tell thee she is: and therefore make her grave

5.play: straight: the crowner hath sat on her, and finds it
notes: Johnson: straight] Make her grave from east to west, in a direct line, parallel to the church; not from north to south, athwart the regular line. Jennens first pointed out that ' straight' here means simply forthwith; and Steevens corroborated it by citations from III, iv, 1; Oth. Ill, iii, 87; Merry Wives, IV, ii, 81. Malone added from Herbert's Jacula Prudentum: ' There is no churchyard so handsome that a man would desire straight to be buried there.' Douce (ii, 261) believes that the Clown refers to the place where the grave should be; suicides were buried on the north side of the church, in unconsecrated ground.
Rushton: crowner] This word is generally supposed to be a corruption of the Clown's, but it is merely the English of the Law Latin coronator, from corona, a crown, which Holinshed also uses.

7.play: First Clown : How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her

10.play: First Clown : It must be 'se offendendo;' it cannot be else. For
notes: Caldecott: se offendendo] Used for se defendendo, a finding of the jury in justifiable homicide.

11.play: here lies the point: if I drown myself wittingly,

12.play: it argues an act: and an act hath three branches: it
notes: Warburton: three branches] Ridicule on scholastic divisions without distinction and of distinctions without difference. Elze calls attention to the frequency in The Hystorie of Hamblet of these threefold ' branches' of the same idea, e.g.: 'rob, pill, and spoyle;' 'A valiant, hardy, and courageous prince;' 'gestures, countenances, and words;' 'time, means, and occasions,' &c. Tschischwitz says that this threefold tautological form belongs to the most ancient Germanic legal usage, and cites Grimm as an authority that it is also true of the Old French. A parallel to the present passage is to be found in Grimm: ' egeris, feceris, gesserisve.'

13.play: is, to act, to do, to perform: argal, she drowned

15.play: Second Clown : Nay, but hear you, goodman delver,--
notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 270): delver] Hence it would appear that the Second Clown is not a gravedigger.

16.play: First Clown : Give me leave. Here lies the water; good: here

17.play: stands the man; good; if the man go to this water,

18.play: and drown himself, it is, will he, nill he, he

19.play: goes,--mark you that; but if the water come to him

20.play: and drown him, he drowns not himself: argal, he

21.play: that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.
notes: Sir John Hawkins: Crowner's Quest law] I strongly suspect that this is in ridicule of a case of forfeiture of a lease to the Crown, reported by Plowden in his 3 Eliza. It seems that Sir James Hales drowned himself in a river in a fit of insanity (produced, it is supposed, by his having been one of the judges who condemned Lady Jane Grey), and the question was whether this did not work a forfeiture to the Crown of his lease. The coroner sat on him, and a verdict of felo de se was rendered. The legal and logical subtilties arising in the course of the case gave a very fair opportunity of sneering at ' Crowner's Quest law': — Walsh said that the act consists of three parts. The first is the imagination, which is a reflection or meditation of the mind, whether or no it is convenient for him to destroy himself, and what way it can be done. The second is the resolution, which is a determination of the mind to destroy himself, and to do it in this or that particular way. The third is the perfection, which is the execution of what the mind has resolved to do. And this perfection consists of two parts, viz. the beginning and the end. The beginning is the doing of the act which causes death, and the end is the death, which is only a sequel to the act.' Much subtilty was expended in finding out whether Sir James was the agent or the patient; or, in other words, whether he went to the water or the water came to him: — ' Sir James Hales was dead, and how came he to his death? It may be answered, by drowning; and who drowned him? Sir James Hales; and when did he drown him? In his life time. So that Sir James Hales being alive caused Sir James Hales to die, and the act of the living man was the death of the dead man. And then for this offence it is reasonable to punish the living man who committed the offence, and not the dead man. But how can he be said to be punished alive when the punishment comes after death ?' &c, &c. Malone thinks that Sh. must have heard of this case in conversation, for it was determined before he was born, and Plowden's Commentaries were not translated until towards the end of the eighteenth century.

22.play: Second Clown : But is this law?

23.play: First Clown : Ay, marry, is't; crowner's quest law.

24.play: Second Clown : Will you ha' the truth on't? If this had not been

25.play: a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out o'
notes: Caldecott: thou say'st] That is, speak'st something to the purpose.
Walker (Crit. iii, 270): Surely, — ' thou say'st true?'

Dyce (ed. 2): The expression is elliptical. [May not the full phrase have been ' thou say'st it,' as we find it in Luke xxiii, 3 ; the mere dental sound, into which, in rapid pronunciation, it degenerates being absorbed by the t of say'st? Ed.]

27.play: First Clown : Why, there thou say'st: and the more pity that

28.play: great folk should have countenance in this world to

29.play: drown or hang themselves, more than their even

30.play: Christian. Come, my spade. There is no ancient
notes: Scene I: Schlegel (ii, 194): The only circumstance from which this piece might be found less theatrical than other tragedies of Sh. is, that in the last scenes the main action either stands still or appears to retrograde. This, however, was inevitable, and lies in the nature of the thing. The whole is intended to show that a consideration, which would exhaust all the relations and possible consequences of a detti to the very limits of human foresight, cripples the power of acting.

Thirlby (Nichols's Illust, ii, 229): even-Christen] was the first to point out that this is equivalent to fellow-Christian, and a remnant of the Anglosaxon emne christen, citing Spelman's Gloss., where Spelman erroneously distinguishes between emne and even. Steevens cites Chaucer: ' Despitous, is he that hath desdayn of his neighebour, that is to say, of his evencristen.' — The Persones Tale, iii, 294, ed. Morris. Nares cites Sir Thos. More's Works, fol. p. 83: ' Proudly judging the lives of their even Christen ;' and ' thei maie not fighte against the Turke, [but] arise in greate plumpes to fighte against their even Christen.' — Ib. p. 277. Clarendon: In Anglo-Saxon we find the compound efen-bisceop, a co-bishop, efen-esne, a fellow-servant. In Forshall and Madden's Glossary to the Wyckliffite Versions of the Bible, we find 'euene-caytif,' a fellow-prisoner, ' euen-seruaunt,' fellow-servant, and others. [Other instances are given in Caldecott ad loc., in Hunter (New Illust. ii, 261), and in The Myroure of oure Ladye (E. E. Text Soc. p. 73): ' we ar en formed to haue . . . loue eche to other, and to all oure euen crystens.' In a note on this passage Blunt cites: ' Therfore Thomas that is seid Didymus, seide to euen disciplis. — Wickliffite N. 71, John xi, 16; and adds: ' The word is also spelt emecristen or emcristen, as in Piers Plowman. It occurs in Swedish in the form jamncristen where j3mn is merely the Swedish spelling of our even.']

31.play: gentleman but gardeners, ditchers, and grave-makers:
notes: Douce (ii, 262): gentleman] Gerard Leigh, one of the oldest writers on Heraldry, speaks of ' Jesus Christ, a gentleman of great linage, and King of the Jewes.' And again, ' Frvr tha* it might be known that even anon after the creation of Adam, there was both gentlenes and ungentlenes, you shall understand that the second man that was born was a gentleman, whose name was Abell. I say a gentleman both of vertue and lignage, with whose sacrifice God was much pleased. His brother Cain was ungentle, for he offered God the worst of his fruites.' — Accedence of Armorie, 1591. There is still a concealed piece of wit in the Clown's allusion to the spade. Adam's spade is set down in some of the books of heraldry as the most ancient form of escutcheons; nor is it improbable that the lower part of this utensil suggested the well-known form of the old triangular shields.

33.play: Second Clown : Was he a gentleman?

34.play: First Clown : He was the first that ever bore arms.

35.play: Second Clown : Why, he had none.

36.play: First Clown : What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the

38.play: could he dig without arms? I'll put another

39.play: question to thee: if thou answerest me not to the

notes: Malone: confess thyself] And be hanged, the Clown would have said if he had not been interrupted. This was a common proverbial sentence. See Oth. IV, i, 39.
Seymour (ii, 198): It may perhaps mean that he is to go to the priest and make confession of heathenish ignorance.

42.play: First Clown : What is he that builds stronger than either the
notes: Steevens: What is he] refers to a collection of similar queries ('which perhaps composed the chief festivity of our ancestors by an evening fire '), preserved in a volume in the University Library at Cambridge. ' The innocence of these Demaundes foyous may deserve a praise which is not always due to their delicacy.' Collier gives a specimen from a small book, called Demaundes joyous, printed by Wynkyn de Worde, 1511: 'Demaunde. What almes is worst bestowed that men gyve? A. That is to a blynde man; for as he hathe ony thynge gyven hym, he wolde, with good wyll, see hym hanged by the necke that gave it hym.'

43.play: mason, the shipwright, or the carpenter?

44.play: Second Clown : The gallows-maker; for that frame outlives a

46.play: First Clown : I like thy wit well, in good faith: the gallows

47.play: does well; but how does it well? it does well to

48.play: those that do in: now thou dost ill to say the

49.play: gallows is built stronger than the church: argal,

50.play: the gallows may do well to thee. To't again, come.
notes: Caldecott: unyoke] That is, unravel this, and your day's work is done, your team you may then unharness.

51.play: Second Clown : 'Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or

53.play: First Clown : Ay, tell me that, and unyoke.

54.play: Second Clown : Marry, now I can tell.

56.play: Second Clown : Mass, I cannot tell.

57.play: Enter HAMLET and HORATIO, at a distance

58.play: First Clown : Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dull
notes: Collier (ed. 1): Yaughan] It is just possible that this was a misspelt stage-direction to inform the player that he was to yawn at this point. Collier (ed. 2): The emendation of the (MS), which we accept, is as much as to say, ' get thee to yon alehouse; fetch me a jug of liquor.' We must suppose the alehouse understood, and pointed to by the First Clo. White: I suspect that this is a misprint for Tavern. But some local allusion understood at the day may lurk under it. J. San (N. & Qu., 5 Oct. 1861): This is merely Shakespeare's English way of representing the Danish Johan,—John. Nicholson (N. & Qu., 29 July, 1871): Most probably Yaughan was the well-known keeper of a tavern near the theatre; and we have three items of corroborative evidence which show: First, that a little before the tirce of this allusion by Sh., which is not found in the Qq, there was about town ' a Jew, one Yohan,' most probably a German Jew, who was a perruquier,—he is mentioned by Jonson in Every Man out of his Humour, V, vi; Second, in The Alchemist, I, i, which was produced eleven years afterwards, Subtle speaks of ' an alehouse, darker than deaf John,' a name which sounds like that of our foreign John, anglicised, and its owner grown deaf by lapse of time; Third, that there was actually an alehouse attached to the Globe Theatre is proved by the ' Sonnett upon the Burneing' of that playhous* 'see Collier's Annals of the Stage, i, 388). Is it then unlikely that our wandering Jew, either in search of a business, or as a profitable extension of his theatrical connection, set up ' the Globe Public-house;' and was thus, as the known refresher of the thirsty actors and audience, mentioned by both Sh. and Jonson ? Clarendon: It is impossible to detect the meaning which lies under this corruption. Elze (Shakespeare- Jahrbuch, xi, 297), who accepts without qualification San's and Nicholson's suggestion, asks whether there be not an allusion to the same Johan in the sneering ' Johannes factotum ' that Greene applies to Sh. C Elliot Browne (Athenaeum, 29 July, 1876): Yaughan is a common Welsh name, and it is surely only necessary to suppose that it was borne by some Welsh tavern-keeper near the theatre.
Clarendon: stoup] This word, meaning a 'drinking-cup,' is still used in college halls. It was applied to vessels of various sizes, and occurs elsewhere in Sh. [See V, ii, 254.]
Jennens: Soope of the Qq represents the clownish pronunciation of sup.

59.play: ass will not mend his pace with beating; and, when
notes: THEOBALD was the first to discover that the Clown here sings some stanzas from a poem, which, because it was printed in a collection of Songes and Sonnettes, written by the ryghl honorable Lorde Henry Howard, late Earle of Surrey, and other, and published by Tottel in 1557, Theobald inferred was written by the noble lord whose name by precedence of rank stood on the title-page. But Gascoigne, who was ten years old when Surrey was beheaded, attributes the poem in question to Lord Vaux, in an Epistle to a Young Gentleman, prefixed to his Posies: 'The L. Vaux his dittie, beginning thus I loath, was thought by some to be made upon his death-bed,' &c. And WARTON, in his Hist, of Eng. Poetry, iii, 45, considers that ' undoubted evidence ' is found that Thomas Lord Vaux was the author, in a manuscript in the British Museum (Harleian MS, 1703) in which we have a copy of this poem, beginning I lothe that I did love, with this title: 'A dyttye or sonet made by the lord Vaus ['vaux,' ap. Arber, p. xiii], in the time of the noble quene Marye, representing the image of Death.'

60.play: you are asked this question next, say 'a

61.play: grave-maker: 'the houses that he makes last till

62.play: doomsday. Go, get thee to Yaughan: fetch me a

65.play: First Clown : He digs and sings
notes: Scene I: Halliwell: Until within a very recent period it was customary for one of the Grave- diggers to preface his labors by divesting himself of about a dozen waistcoats, an operation which always created great merriment, and which, perhaps, had come down by tradition from the players of Shakespeare's own time. The Doctor, in The Duchess of Malfi, according to a stage-direction in ed. 1708, 'puts off his four cloaks, one after another,' — a similar stratagem to create the laughter of the audience.

66.play: In youth, when I did love, did love,

73.play: HAMLET : 'Tis e'en so: the hand of little employment hath

notes: Clarendon: daintier] Compare Tro. & Cres. I, i, 59.

Bucknill (p. 119): sense] This line is but half truth. Does custom blunt the fingers of a watchmaker, the eyes of a printer, or the auditory nerve of a musician? Did the grave-digger do his own sombre work with less skill because he had been accustomed to it for thirty years? Custom blunts our sensations to those impressions which we do not attend to, and it sharpens them to those which we do. Custom in Ham. himself had sharpened the speculative faculties which he exercised, while it had dulled the active powers which depend upon that resolution which he did not practise.

notes: Clarke: jowls] If proof were wanted of the exquisite propriety and force of effect with which Sh. uses words, and words of even homely fashion, there could hardly be a more pointed instance than the verb ' jowls ' here. What strength it gives to the impression of the head and cheek-bone smiting against the earth! and how it makes the imagination feel the bruise in sympathy!

III, i, 73.] Johnson: It is a strong exaggeration to remark, that an ass can over-reach him who would once have tried to circumvent — . I believe both the words of the Qq and Ff were Shakespeare's. An author in revising his work, when his original ideas have faded from his mind, and new observations have produced new sentiments, easily introduces images which have been more newly impressed upon him, without observing their want of congruity to the general texture of his original design. Jennens: It is applied to a politician, not as an insolent office, but as a circumventing, scheming, man. CORSON: The Ff, without doubt, give the more expressive term.

notes: Nares: mazzard] Ahead; usually derived, but with very little probability, from machoirc, French, which means only a jaw. The fact is, that it has always been a burlesque word, and was as likely to be made from mazer, a bowl, as from anything else; comparing the head to a large goblet. Wedgwood confirms Nares's derivation. 'In a similar way, Italian zucca, properly a gourd, and thence a drink ing cup, is used to signify a skull.'

97.play: but to play at loggats with 'em? mine ache to think on't.
notes: Clarendon: loggats] The nature of this game has been much discussed, but what appears to be the most exact description is thus given by Clarendon: ' "Loggats," diminutive of log. The game so called resembles bowls, but with notable differences. First, it is played not on a green, but on a floor strewed with ashes. The Jack is a wheel of lignum-vitae or other hard wood, nine inches in diameter and three or four inches thick. The loggat, made of apple- wood, is a truncated cone 26 or 27 inches in length, tapering from a girth of 8½ or 9 inches at the one end to 6½ or 4 inches at the other. Each player has three loggats which he throws, holding lightly the thin end. The object is to lie as near the Jack as possible. The only place we have heard of where this once popular game is now played is the Hampshire Hog Inn, Norwich. We have to thank the Rev. G. Gould for a detailed description of the game, which we have abridged as above. Perhaps Ham. meant to compare the skull to the Jack at which the bones were thrown. In Jonson's Tale of a Tub, IV, vi: "Now are they tossing of his legs and arms Like loggats at a pear tree."'
